, No. 13, Bath-place, New-road;" I went, and took another guitar with me; he wished me to fetch my elegant guitar; two or three days afterwards I found the guitar I had first lent him at a pawnbroker's, in St. Martin's-lane, and two other instruments - the prisoner came to me that day; I told him I had found where he had pawned my instruments, and if he did not return them I would have him arrested; he then gave me up the duplicates of these two guitars, and a harp - this is the one I first lent him.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You teach music, and deal in musical instruments? A. Yes; he had all three of the guitars in his possession - I leat him one, and these other two were sold; I had not sold him the three, to he paid for in three months; I had not asked him to return the one I left him - I went to a great many pawnbrokers, because I suspected I had got with a set of swindlers; I did stand once where the prisoner now does, but I went out with very great honour; you scolded my wife very much - I was charged with bigamy.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in St. Martin's-lane. I have a guitar, which was pawned for 1l. 10s., but not by the prisoner - this is the duplicate.
PROSECUTOR. This is one he gave me.
Prisoner's Defence. He sold me the three instruments before two witnesses.

GUILTY . - Aged 49. -
Judgment Respited .

1289.
JOHN MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of May , 1 handkerchief, value 2s, 6d., the goods of
James Cumming
, from his person .

JAMES CUMMING. I am a surgeon , and live at Tavistock-place. On the evening of the 2nd of May I was in Upper King-street, Bloomsbury
; I heard a cry of Stop thief! missed my handkerchief, and saw the prisoner pursued by Mr. Rix - he was secured with my handkerchief in his possession, which he said I had dropped.

WILLIAM RIX. I am a plumber. I was in Upper King-street, and saw the prisoner and another person; I saw the handkerchief taken from the pocket of a gentleman, who, I believe, was the prosecutor, the prisoner was within a yard of the person who took it; and the other person gave it to the prisoner, who put it into his breast pocket - I cried Stop thief! and the prisoner ran into a mews, I took him there; I had lost sight of him, but I know he is the person.
WILLIAM JAMES. (Police-constable E 17). I received prisoner, and found this handkerchief on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Six Months .

1290.
EDMUND WEBSTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of April , 1 copper, value 25s.; and 1 copper pot, value 15s., the goods of
Sarah Waterfield
; and fixed to a building ; against the Statute.

JOHN CALLER
(Police-constable S 67). On the morning of the 30th of April, about half-past six o'clock, I saw the prisoner in Pancras-road, carrying this copper and pot in a bag - I asked if he had not got a copper; he said Yes, that he had found these articles in a field, and was going to take them to the station-house; I said he had better go to the station with me - he said he had no objection, but when he had got a few steps, he put them down and said I might take them; I took them, but was forced to put them down once or twice to take hold of him, as he was very obstinate; I went to the Adam and Eve, in Pancras-road, and found the wash-house door had been broken open, and this chisel was there, which exactly corresponded with the marks on the door; the copper was missed, but the bricks had been pulled down, and we could not fit it.

SARAH WATERFIELD
. I am a widow , and keep the Adam and Eve
. The officer called me up - I missed a copper and a pot; I am sure these are mine; I had seen them safe on the Saturday night, and this was on the Monday morning.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in search of work, and saw these articles in a bag; I was going to take them to the station-house.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1291.
ROBERT WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 3 chisels, value 1s.; 1 pair of compasses, value 6d.; 1 gouge, value 6d.; 2 gimblets, value 6d., and 3 files, value 6d., the goods of
Henry Bull
; 4 chisels, value 2s., and 2 gimblets, value 8d. , the goods of
John Syrett
.

THOMAS WILSON
(Police-constable T 59). On the night of the 1st of May I was on duty at Hyde-park-terrace
, about eight o'clock; I went to the back of the buildings; I then went by a ladder into an attic of an unfurnished house, and found the prisoner there, with these articles on him - I asked how he came there; he made no answer.

HENRY BULL
. I am a carpenter , and was at work at these houses. On the morning of the 2nd of May, when I went to work, I missed some tools, which I had left there; some of these are mine, and some belong to
John Syrett
.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1292.
THOMAS ATKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of May , 1 umbrella, value 8s., and 1 hat, value 5s. , the goods of
Richard Molineux
.

JOHN TODD
. I am an ironmonger, and live in Bury-street, Bloomsbury. On the 5th of May I met the prisoner in Bury-street, with an umbrella and a hat -I stopped him - Mr. Molineux came up and claimed them; he was taken into custody - he wanted me to go up the street, and said he would point out the person who gave them to him.

RICHARD MOLINEUX
. I am a coach-wheelwright , and live in Little Russell-street
; I came up while Mr. Todd had hold of the prisoner, who was scuffling to get away -I knew the hat and umbrella immediately, and gave him in charge; I had seen them in my passage half an hour before - my house is two hundred yards from where he was taken.

JOHN CARNEY
. (Police-constable E 34). I received the prisoner; he said a man gave these things to him, but did not say where he was to take them.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1293.
WILLIAM ANDREWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 1 saw, value 3s., and 1 knife, value 8s. , the goods of
Isaac Clift
.

ISAAC CLIFT
. I live in Holywell-lane, Shoreditch
, and am a patten-manufacturer . I employed the prisoner on the 10th of April; when the men left work, I missed a saw from the shop - the prisoner came to work on the 11th, and I went into the shop, and asked him and the rest of the men if they knew any thing of it; the prisoner said he had taken it to a man where he lodged, and would go and get it - I missed my knife that day, and from information I found them in pledge; the prisoner absconded the day I missed my knife; he came on the following Friday, and I had him taken - he begged my pardon, and said he would make any arrangement, if I would not prosecute him.

THOMAS STEVENS
. I am a fellow-workman of the prisoner's. On the 10th of April I met him in Shoreditch - he told me had taken the saw, and pawned it for 6d.; on the Wednesday I heard him in the passage - he said,"Larry, bring the knife up, I want to take it to be ground."

JAMES ASHLEY
. I am apprentice to a pawnbroker, in Shoreditch. I have a saw, pawned by the prisoner, for 1s. on the 10th of April.

JOHN NEALE
. I am assistant to a pawnbroker. I have a patten-knife, pawned on the 11th of April, to the best of my belief, by the prisoner - I know I have seen him there.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he could not get his wages, and had pledged the saw to obtain victuals.

ISAAC CLIFT
. I did not owe him any thing.
NOT GUILTY .

1294.
HENRY BROUGHTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of April , 1 coat, value 7s. , the property of
John Morgan
.

PHILIP JONES
(Police-constable N 217). On the 26th of April I was at my window in Church-street, Hackney - I saw the prisoner coming down the grove with a great coat; two more men were behind him - he was walking very fast, and when he turned into the main road, he ran as fast as he could; I ran after him for about ten minutes, and took him - while he was running he threw the coat down in the dirt; this is it - he said at the station that he bought it of the two men who were with him, for 2s. - the other two had run off; it was a quarter before eight o'clock in the morning, and he was coming from the prosecutor's.

JOHN MORGAN
. I am in the employ of Mr. Barber, of Hackney
; I attend his stage-coaches . On the 26th of April I placed my great coat in a chaise, in his coach-house, about seven o'clock in the morning - I missed it at eight, and saw it afterwards in possession of the officer.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had bought the coat of two men in Hackney-fields.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1295.
CATHERINE BROOKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of April , 1 pair of trousers, value 10s. , the goods of
Thomas Stafford
and
John Stafford
.

JAMES TRAIL
. I am in the employ of Thomas and John Stafford, pawnbrokers
, St. John-street
. On the evening of the 12th of April, the prisoner came into the shop with another woman to pawn a shawl - while this was going on, the prisoner went to the door, and looked at a pair of trousers which were tied to an iron bar, and I suppose she untied them - she then came back to the counter - went out, and came in again - then went out and took the trousers; I went and found her with them two doors off; I think she was intoxicated.

WILLIAM CLEMENTS
(Police-constable G 82). I took the prisoner; she said the woman who was with her took them down, gave them to her, and desired her to run off with them.
GUILTY . Aged 37.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1296.
GEORGE BRIANT
was indicted for
stealing' on the 29th of February , 1 saw, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Keen
; 1 saw, value 8s., the goods of
Thomas Clapton
; and 1 apron, value 6d. , the goods of
James Harwin
.

THOMAS JOHNSON
(Police-constable G 81). I took the prisoner and another man into custody on a charge of common assault; I found on the prisoner twenty-four duplicates, in a purse - some of them relate to the tools in question; I have found three persons who claim some of them - this apron I found on him also.

JOHN DAVIS
. I am servant to Mr. Cordwell, a pawnbroker, in Exmouth-street. I have three saws, two ploughs, and other articles, pawned at his shop - these are the duplicates of them.

GEORGE FRY
. I am in the service of Mr. Lorton, a pawnbroker. I have two saws, pawned on the 29th of April - this is the duplicate, but I did not take them in.

THOMAS KEEN
. This saw is mine - I lost it on the 29th of February, and this other saw is
Thomas Clapton
's - I went with the officer to take the prisoner, and found on him this apron, which belongs to another workman; there were several other saws and tools lost.

JAMES HARWIN
. This is my apron, and was in the same shop as the tools were.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the apron in Oxford-street - they have all sworn false against me; I found the duplicates - I put them into a cupboard in my room.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Transported for Seven Years

1297.
JOHN BALDWIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 waistcoat, value 14s. , the goods of
John Foster
.

JOHN FOSTER
. I live in Queen-street, Edgware-road
. I had seen the prisoner at my son-in-law's, and asked him to assist me to move a few things - I then missed my waistcoat.

HENRY RIDER
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Chelsea. I took in this waistcoat from the prisoner on the 2nd of April, and lent 3s. on it; I am certain of his person.

RICHARD BART
(Police-constable T 75). The prosecutor came to my house, and said he had lost a waistcoat; I took the prisoner.

JOHN FOSTER
. This is my waistcoat - I lost this and a great many other things.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 15.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury -
Confined 14 Days .

1298.
BENJAMIN BREWER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 2 trusses of hay, value 5s., and 3 bushels of oats and chaff, mixed together, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Cobley, the younger
.

THOMAS COBLEY
, JUN. I am a carman , and live in Essex-street, Whitechapel
. I had a cart in my yard, loaded with dung, on the 1st of May; it was just going to start -I received information, and examined it; I found under the tilt two trusses of hay, similar to that which I had in my loft - it was the prisoner's business to drive that cart ; I spoke to him about it - he said he got it on the road, and then said he did not know how it came there - I sent for an officer, and took him; after he was gone to the station a sack of oats and chaff was found in the cart.

JOHN KEMBER
. I am foreman to the prosecutor. On the 1st of May the cart of dung was there, and two trusses of hay and a sack of oats and chaff mixed together, were found in it; I had been in the loft, and counted the trusses of clover hay - I then went to breakfast; the prisoner was loading the dung - when I came back he was still doing the same; I went into the loft and counted the hay again, and missed two trusses - I know he had not hay in his cart when he came to the yard; the two trusses were found on the copse in front of the cart - they were of the same sort as those in the loft, and made up the forty-four which I had at first counted - he first said he found it on the road, and then that he did not know how it got there; we had some mixed oats and chaff in the loft, but we could not miss any of them - that found in his cart corresponds with it exactly, and the sack, in which they were found seemed to be one which he had brought empty.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to get a pint of beer; I do not know who put them there.
GUILTY . Aged 30.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Month .

1299.
WILLIAM BULL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 1 carpet, value 18s. , the goods of
William Clack
.

SARAH CLACK
. I am the wife of William Clack, a baker , who lives at Hertford. I came to town, and on the 10th of April I was going from Shoreditch
to Bethnal-green-road
- I had a carpet with me with a string attached to it; the prisoner came up, and caught hold of the parcel- he let it go; he caught it a second time, and tugged at it till he broke the string, and made away with it; he ran down Wentworth-street, and turned to the left - I am quite positive he is the person; I observed his features very particularly - he had a dark coat, a shabby black hat, and corderoy trousers on; there was a person brought up to me afterwards, who was not the man - I saw the prisoner in custody on the 21st, and knew him; I gave 18s. 6d. for the carpet -
Mary Crawley
was with me; I have not seen it since - a number of people came about me, but gave me no assistance; I went to a public-house, at the corner, and applied to the landlord, but he gave me no assistance; the officer then came - I gave him information, and describedthe person who had robbed me; when I had passed Shoreditch church it was a quarter before twelve o'clock, and about five minutes after I was robbed, the officer took out his watch, and said it was half-past twelve.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Is that a place of great thoroughfare? A. I should consider so - it must have taken me more than half an hour to go there from Shoreditch church - I was a good deal agitated, but I am not deceived in the person; I did not say before the Magistrate that the man had a light jacket on - I always said it was a dark coat; another person was taken from my description, but that was not the person.

MARY CRAWLEY
. I am sister to Mrs. Clarck. I was with her in Brick-lane - I am positive the prisoner is the person who took the parcel; my sister appealed to the people about to assist, but nobody did; I saw the prisoner's face - he had a dark coat on, a shabby black hat, and corderoy trousers.

Cross-examined. Q.I suppose you were a good deal frightened? A. Yes, but I noticed the person of the prisoner; I did not see him again for eleven days - I am sure my sister did not say he had a light jacket on, or a light coat.

MARY ANN FOSTER
. I am the wife of
John Foster
- we live in London-street, London-road; the prisoner's father and mother occupy my front parlour - they have lodged with me four months; the prisoner lived with them. I recollect, on the 10th of April, I went into their room for rent - I saw the prisoner and his mother there; she was ill in bed, and was mending his trousers, which I believe were corderoy or fustian, and he had a short jacket on, either fustain or corderoy - it was a dark colour; my house is a mile and a half from Wentworth-street; as near as I can judge it was twelve o'clock, for directly I left I went to get my little boy from school; I left the prisoner in the room, waiting for his trousers.

SAMUEL PRENDERGRASS
. I am an officer of Lambeth-street. On the 10th of April I was in Old Montague-street, opposite to Wentworth-street - I went to a public-house, and saw the prosecutrix there, complaining of her loss; she was much agitated - I asked her particularly the description of the person, in consequence of which I apprehended a man in five or six minutes afterwards; she said he was not the man - she then described the prisoner; I looked at my watch when I had been two or three minutes in the house - it was half-past twelve o'clock, but I afterwards found my watch was a quarter of an hour too slow.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you make an entry of the charge in the book? A. Yes - she said he had a fustian or a light jacket on, that he was about five feet four inches high, and of a pale complexion.

JAMES JOHN CONNOLEY
(Police-constable H 135). I received information on the 13th of April, and on the 14th I saw the prisoner coming out of Wentworth-street with two others - I followed them; the prisoner was going to turn into a passage on the right-hand side, towards Whitechapel, but he saw me, left his companious, and crossed the road; I went to him, and said, "I think I want you, I am not certain - will you go with me to Bethnal-green-road?" he asked what I wanted with him - I said that was not a usual thing to state there, because if he was not the person it would be generally circulated; he then went with me to No. 51, Bethnal-green-road, where
Mary Crawley
lives - she came down stairs, and before she got into the shop, she said, "That is the man that robbed my sister;" he said,"You must be mistaken;" I took him to the station, booked the charge, and he was sent to the office - he was remanded till the following Saturday, when Mrs. Clack attended - there were sixteen or twenty persons together, but she picked him out from the others; she said she was quite certain of him by his face.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not nearer to Whitechapel on that day than London-bridge; I then went to Euston-square, to see for my uncle; I did not leave my father till past one o'clock.

MARY ANN COLLINS
. I live in the same house with the prisoner. On the 10th of April I met the prisoner and his father in the London-road, about half-past twelve o'clock; I was going to the public-house for my dinner beer when my father came home - there is a clock at the public-house.
COURT. Q. Are you quite sure you noticed the clock? A. Yes, I went on purpose to see the time and for the beer; they were going towards the Elephant and Castle.

JOSEPH BULL
. I am the prisoner's father. On the 10th of April I left my house with my son, at twenty minutes past twelve o'clock, and we came to a public-house in the Borough.

COURT. Q. Had you seen Mrs. Foster before you left? A. Yes I had; we came from the London-road towards the Elephant and Castle - we met
Mary Ann Collins
; we came over to St. George's church, and went into a wine-vaults there - I had a pint of ale for my dinner; I had brought my own victuals from home, as my wife was very ill, and that is a house I always call at; I was coming to my brother's, in Golden-lane - I did not go near Wentworth-street; I left my son at Cannon-street, and told him I did not want him to go any further.
NOT GUILTY .

1300.
JOSEPH BATES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of May , 2 sovereigns and 1 shilling , the monies of
William Burley
.

WILLIAM BURLEY
. I am postillion to Lord Beverley, who lives in Portman-square
. I missed two sovereigns out of a portmanteau in April, and then I missed some silver - the coachman then marked a sovereign and ten shillings, and I put them in the portmanteau from which I had lost the other money; I went to it at half-past eight o'clock the next morning, which was the 8th of May, and I missed a marked shilling and a marked sovereign from there; I asked the prisoner to lend me a shilling, which he did - I asked him to lend me another, which he did, and the second one was the marked shilling I had missed from the portmanteau; it must have been got by forcing open the portmanteau at one end of the lid.

JAMES FRUIN. I am servant to Lord Beverley's eldest son. On the 8th of May the prisoner asked me for change for a sovereign, which I gave him - the sovereign I received from him I gave to the officer.

JOSEPH WELLS
. I am coachman to Lord Beverley. I marked a sovereign and ten shillings; this is the sovereign, and this is one of theshillings.

WILLIAM GREEN
(Police-constable D 114). I took theprisoner. I found on him ten shillings, three half-crowns and 2s. 6d.; I asked what he had done with the sovereign; he said he had got change from the servant in the house, and the servant produced the sovereign - I asked how he came to do this; he said he was going out of town with his master, and he had put his hand into the trunk and taken out the sovereign and the shilling, with an intention of returning them.
The prisoner received an excellent character, and one witness engaged to employ him.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1301.
THOMAS BLAIR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of April , 1 time-piece, value 10s.; 1 ewer, value 6d.; 1 basin, value 6d.; 1 case of drawing-instruments, value 6s., and 1 neck-chain, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Henry Richards
, his master .

THOMAS HENRY RICHARDS
. I am an auctioneer - I live in Worship-street
, but I have an auction-room in Brown's-lane
; the prisoner has been employed there for me upwards of two years; I lost a time-piece from the mantel-piece there, and the ewer and the basin from Worship-street, where we had a sale; I lost a case of instruments and a neck-chain, the case from a drawer, where I believe he had put it, and the chain from the parlour, where I had put it when I took it off my wife's watch.

ELIZABETH STEPHENS. I am single. I have been living with the prisoner nearly seven years; we lodge at Great Saffron-hill; he brought home the time-piece when we lived at Finsbury-court - it was there four or five months; he told me to pawn it, and I did; he brought home a case of instruments when we lived at Saffron-hill, and the neck-chain, which he gave me for my little girl to play with.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. When did you first see the time-piece? A. Eight or nine months age - he had made use of his master's money, and he told me to pawn the time-piece - I pawned it in my own name; it had stood on a sideboard, and was not concealed; I was not quarrelling with the prisoner when the officer came - he knocked me down.
JOHN BATEMAN. I am a pawnbroker. I have the time-piece, pawned by Stephens, on the 24th of March.

THOMAS HENRY RICHARDS
. This is my time-piece, and so are the other articles.

Cross-examined. Q.What character had the prisoner? A. I considered him trust worthy - I never trusted this time-piece to him; I had no transaction with him in a way of business - the time-piece was for the use of our office, and when it was missed he charged another person with stealing it; I was once in the Court of Exchequer for selling some goods for a man, who afterwards took the benefit of the Act, and I had to pay the fine; I have borrowed 5l. of the prisoner's brother, but I never had any money transaction with the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. The time-piece was not pawned by my order.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Six Months .

1302.
GEORGE CHAPMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April , 5 feet of leaden pipe, value 2s., and 1 metal cock, value 6d., the goods of
William Cooper
, the same being fixed to a building; against the Statute .
The prosecutor being a lodger, and only having the use of the articles, the prisoner was ACQUITTED .

1303.
WILLIAM DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , 1 bag, value 4d.; 1 sovereign, 3 shillings, and 1 sixpence , the property of
Joseph Foster
.

JOSEPH FOSTER
. I keep a ham and beef shop in Lower Seymour-street
. On the afternoon of the 16th of May the prisoner and another lad came to the shop, and asked for two 1d. saveloys; I said I had no 1d. ones, they should have two for 2 1/2d. - the prisoner paid 1 1/2d. for one, and left the shop; I went and spoke to my wife on the stairs - I then came into the shop, and saw the prisoner behind the counter, at the end of it; I asked what he wanted- he said, "You said we should have two for 2 1/2d.," and he threw down 1d. and took a saveloy; I went to put the penny into the till, and missed the money stated - I ran after the prisoner, and brought him back to my shop; he threw something away, went down on his knees, and begged pardon; he afterwards showed me my money in a dish- there was the bag and 1l. 3s. 6d. in it; I am sure it had been in my till; I had counted it ten minutes before they came in.

JAMES WELLS
(Police-constable S 30). I was called to take the prisoner - I saw a dish in the shop; I took from it this bag, with 1l. 3s. 6d. in it: I took the prisoner into the parlour, and found a saveloy on him - he went on his knees, begged the prosecutor to forgive him, and said he would do so no more.

JOSEPH FOSTER
re-examined. Q. Are you sure you saw him throw something towards the dish? A. He made a motion that way; I did not see it go, but he pointed it out in the dish, among the gravy.
Prisoner's Defence. I went for a saveloy - a boy ran from behind the counter, and I asked him for it; he went to some beef, and began to pick it.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1304.
WILLIAM CHILMADE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of April , 1 pair of trousers, value 8s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 3s.; 1 shirt, value 4s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Joseph Bishop
, his master .

JOSEPH BISHOP
. I am a clothes-salesman , and live in Goswell-street
- the prisoner was my errand-boy for nearly twelve months. On the 12th of April a pair of trousers were discovered under the stairs; I left them there, and in the evening I sent him out - the trousers were then gone, and the officer took him with them.

JOHN MARTIN
(Police-constable G 202). I apprehended the prisoner on the 12th of April; I took him into his master's house, and found this pair of trousers under his own; I went to his lodging, and found a pair of shoes, and on his person I found a duplicate of a coat, waistcoat, shirt, and handkerchief.

JAMES JONES
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a coat, waistcoat, and shirt, pawned for 1l. 2s., by
Ann Chilmade
, who is not here.

JOHN FOY
. I apprehended Ann Chilmade.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. On the 1st of April I went home to my father's: all their things were sold off, and I pawned what I had of my own - I did not know how to get them again, and I pawned these things.
GUILTY . Aged 20.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Six Weeks .

1305.
WILLIAM CROSSLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of April , 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
George Henry Hinkins
.

GEORGE HENRY HINKINS
. I live in Golden-lane
, and deal in new and second-hand shoes . On the 27th of April the Policeman came and asked me if I had not lost some shoes; I then missed a pair from the step of the door - I went with him, and saw them at the pawnbroker's.

THOMAS KIRKWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Brick-lane, Old-street. I took in these shoes from the prisoner on the evening of the 26th of April.

WILLIAM PURCELL
(Police-constable C 194). I took the prisoner from information, and found the shoes.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not take them - it was another boy.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1306.
JOSEPH EMMINGTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March , 3 pieces of wood, value 2s. , the goods of
Charles Hamilton
.

WILLIAM HUMPHREVS. I was at work at Mr. Charles Hamilton's park, about a mile from Harrow
- I missed several pieces of wood, but I cannot tell on what day - it was about the 17th or 18th of March; I lost a great deal: I found these three pieces at the prisoner's, on the 4th of April, about three hundred yards from where I was at work; he is a labourer, but was not at work there - we put our tools into the house he lodged in, and when we were fetching them I saw this wood; we called his wife, and asked if it was here - she said, "You touch it if you dare;" I sent for the officer, and took it - I know this is part of the wood I lost, by my own work on it.

HENRY CORBY
. I am a constable. I took the wood.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had found the wood in question by the road side.
NOT GUILTY .

1307.
HENRY FAULKNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , 5 lbs. of pork, value 1s. 8d. , the goods of
George Milton Southcombe
.

JOHN BINDEN
. I am in the service of
George Milton Southcombe
, a cheesemonger , of Shoreditch
. On the 14th of April we had three legs of pork hanging in the shop - about half-past ten o'clock in the evening I went for half a pint of beer; when I had drank my beer I missed one leg - I followed the prisoner, who was eight or ten yards off, and took it from his basket; he gave it up willingly; I had not sold it - I cannot swear that it was ours, but I missed one like it.

WILLIAM TREMAIN BRAND
(Police-constable H 35). I took the prisoner and this pork.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going by with the basket, and a person said there was some meat dropped - I took this piece of pork up, and was looking at it at the next window; the shopman asked what I was going to do with it - I said, "Is it yours?" he said Yes, and took it.
NOT GUILTY .

1308.
CHARLES FRIBURG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of April , 1 picture and frame, value 2s. , the goods of
John Whitehouse
.

WILLIAM BONEVAL CHURCH
(Police-serjeant T 2). On the 22nd of April I fell in with the prisoner, as I was going my rounds at Hammersmith, at a quarter-past twelve o'clock at night - I saw he had something under his arm, and as he passed me, he brought it round to his breast; I followed, and asked what he had got; he said he had it from his father's - I said I would go there with him; when we got near his house, he said his father did not give it to him, but some person whom he did not know; I took him to the station-house, and in going along he called on some men to rescue him, but I prevented that, and took him to the station; I found this picture on him, which I recollected having seen at Whitehouse's.

JOHN WHITEHOUSE
. I am a publican , and live at Hammersmith
. This picture was taken from my parlour; it is the Spanish Patriot - the prisoner had been there that Saturday evening.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 26.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1309.
CHARLES GOODALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of May , 2 live tame rabbits, price 6s., the property of
John Lief
: 1 saw, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Richard West
; and 1 pewter pot, value 1s. , the goods of
William Sweeting
.

JOHN BANKS
(Police-constable N 62). On the 2nd of May, at half-past two o'clock in the morning, I was in Bacchuswalk, Hoxton, and saw the prisoner lurking about; he ran off and I pursued; I took him and found on him this property.

RICHARD LIEF
. I live in Turner's-square
. On this morning I lost two rabbits from my hutches - I had fastened them up the night before at half-past six o'clock, they were then alive; they were dead when the officer found them on the prisoner; these are their skins - he must have got over two walls to get them; mine is the sixth house.

RICHARD WEST
. This saw, which the officer found on the prisoner, is mine; it was in my back premises in a little cupboard, fastened with a button; in the morning I found the cupboard open, and missed the saw; I live next door to Mr. Lief.

MARY SWEETING
. I am the wife of
William Sweeting
. Our yard joins the other, I lost this pot from our back yard, and these two cocks belong to the landlord of the house.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1310.
GEORGE HACK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of May , 4 pairs of shoes; value 14s. , the goods of
Joseph William Snell
.

JOSEPH WILLIAM SNELL
. I am a shoemaker , and live at the corner of Cannon-street-road
; the prisoner's wife has worked for me for four or five years - the prisoner is a servant out of place . I placed a pair of shoes on a boardon the 3rd of May; the prisoner came to my shop about twelve o'clock - I left him, and went down stairs; when I came up, my wife had sent him out; I missed the shoes, and when he came back I spoke to him - he said, "You can't suspect me - I have no property about me;" the officer then came, searched him, and found the shoes in his coat pocket - I had missed some before.
Cross-examined by Mr. LEE. Q.Was there any mark on these shoes? A. Yes.
JOHN CRIDDLE (Police-constable H 142). I was sent for, and took the prisoner. I found these shoes in his pocket, and this duplicate of another pair in his fob.
SAMUEL STEVENS. I am a pawnbroker. I have two pairs of shoes, pawned with me - I do not know by whom, but I gave this duplicate for them.
MR. SNELL. These are all mine.
Cross-examined. Q. Had the prisoner's wife been there that day? A.No, not for some years - the prisoner always brought the work home.
The prisoner received an excellent character,
GUILTY . Aged 40.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Month .

1311.
JAMES HARRISON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , 2 pillow-cases, value 3s. , the goods of
John Welford
.
FRANCIS SHIRLEY. I am a pawnbroker. I have two pillow-cases, which were pawned, on the 14th of April, by the prisoner.

JOHN WALKER
. I am an upholsterer, and live in Newman-street
- the prisoner was in my employ as a French polisher . I had some property of Mr. Welford's to take care of; it was in drawers in my bed-room, which the prisoner had access to.

JOHN WELFORD
. These pillow-cases are mine; I had left them in Mr. Walker's care,
Prisoner's Defence. There were a great many more people going in and out the place; I know nothing of this property - I bought the duplicate.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1312.
GEORGE HOWARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 1 pair of boots, value 7s., and 1 pair of shoes, value 5s. , the goods of
James Pope
.

JAMES POPE. I am a farmer , and live at Finchley
; the prisoner had worked for me in the hay time. These boots and shoes were taken from a room adjoining the house where they clean them, and where the man sleeps.

SAMUEL AADY
. I am a labourer. The prisoner came to my house on the 12th of February, about twelve or one o'clock, and asked me to lend him a knife and a brush to clean these shoes - I lent them to him; he cleaned them, and put the boots on - he sat a little while, and then offered the shoes to me for sale; I had not money enough, but I gave him half a crown and an old shirt - he then went away with the boots on; when I heard that such things were lost I made inquiry, and gave them up - these are them.
WILLIAM MORRIS. I am a constable. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I worked for Mr. Pope a long while - he never knew such a thing of me.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1313.
JOSEPH KING
was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April , 1 pair of trousers, value 12s. , the goods of
James Leach
.

CHARLES BURNS
. I live with Mr. Fuller. Mr.
James Leach
's shop is opposite to us; on the 9th of April, I saw the prisoner standing by the lamp-post, and my mistress told me to watch him - he went towards the square; another young man snatched a pair of trousers from Mr. Leach's door, gave them to the prisoner, and they both went away; I gave the alarm - the prisoner was taken.

HENRY ROBERTS
. I am in the employ of Mr.
James Leach
, a pawnbroker . Burns gave me information - I pursued the prisoner, and think I saw him throw away these trousers; I took them up - they are my master's.

JOHN GEORGE BRAUND
. I saw a mob, and went up; a gentleman had hold of the prisoner, and said he had stolen a pair of trousers.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1314.
JOHN LAWRENCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 yard of floor-cloth, value 4s., the goods of
Samuel Ames
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

MARY BRANBURY. I live near Mr.
Samuel Ames
' shop, at Islington
. On the 1st of April I saw the prisoner shake a piece of floor-cloth; he shook it a second time, then put it down by his side, covered it with some cloth, and took it away from the stone coping.

RICHARD REYNOLDS. I work for Mr. Ames. Branbury's husband informed me of this; I pursued the prisoner about one hundred yards; he had this floor-cloth, and was walking off - he gave it to me, and I took him.

WILLIAM HOLT
(Police-constable N 17). I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JAMES CHAMBERS
. I am a Police-constable. I produce a certificate of the conviction of the prisoner, which I got at Mr. Clark's office; I was a witness, and know he is the man.
Prisoner. I was in distress.

GUILTY . Aged 55. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1315.
CATHERINE LATCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 1 watch, value 30s. , the goods of
William Knight
.

WILLIAM KNIGHT
. I lost my watch at Mr. Harley's, a publican; I think it was about the middle of January -I went to his house about that time, pulled off my coat, hung it across a chair, and sat there half an hour; I took my coat, came out, and put it on; I missed my watch from the coat pocket the next morning; I had put it there to prevent its being scratched with some money which I had in my pocket - I do not know that I saw the prisoner, but she lived servant there.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. You had your watch in your waistcoat pocket before? A. I had it there then, and took it out and put it into my coat pocket, but I had another watch in my fob - it was not a club night; I went to see Mr. Harley - it might have fallen out.

MICHAEL HARLEY
. I am a publican - the prisoner lived servant with me from November to January. On the morning after the prosecutor had been at my house he said he had lost his watch, but we had no suspicion of the prisoner - another watch was missed afterwards, and she was searched, on the 11th of April, and Mr. Knight's watch was found up her sleeve; she said she was an honest woman.
NOT GUILTY .

1316.
THOMAS BALSTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of May , 4 lbs. weight of sugar, value 3s., the the goods of
Robert Baker
, his master .

ROBERT BAKER. I live in High-street, Marylebone
-I am a publican . The prisoner has been employed in grinding malt for me; I did not miss this sugar, but saw the prisoner come from my store-room, and suspected something wrong - I sent for an officer; he took the prisoner, and found 4 1/2 lbs. of sugar on him - he said he was very sorry, and hoped I would forgive him; it is lump sugar, such as we use to sweeten gin.

DANIEL DUTCH
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the 2nd of May - this is the sugar.
GUILTY . Aged 49.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1317.
JANE MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of May , 1 shift, value 2s., and 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
Susannah Church
.

SARAH DUNAWAY. I lived where the prosecutrix does, in Foley-place, Tottenham-court-road
. On the 5th of May I saw the prisoner on the stairs; she took a shift and handkerchief off the line, which had been there a quarter of an hour - she was going away; I called out - she threw them down, and I took them; I pursued, and sent for an officer.

SUSANNAH CHURCH
. I am single . These are my property; I know the prisoner.
Prisoner. It was extreme distress.

GUILTY . Aged 60. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1318.
ELIZABETH MOORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May , 1 gown, value 5s., and 1 shirt, value 4s. , the goods of
George Ravenor
.

NATHANIEL SCRIVENOR
. I am in the employ of Mr.
George Ravenor
, pawnbroker , Brompton
. The prisoner was an old customer; she came on the 12th of May; I watched her, saw her take down a shirt, and walk away with it - she got outside the door; I took her with it - she said distress drove her to it; I believe up to this time she had a good character.
JOHN POINTING (Police-serjeant T 6). I took the prisoner, and have the shirt - the gown had been taken an hour before.
GEORGE GEVER. I have a gown, pawned on the 12th of May, by Ann Goodwin.

ANN GOODWIN
. I pawned it by desire of Smison.

JANE SMISON
. I received it from the prisoner, and gave it to Goodwin to pawn.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 43.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1319.
ANDREW PETERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of April , 1 waistcoat, value 2s. , the goods of
Barnett Marks
.

BARNETT MARKS. I am a slopseller , and live at Shadwell
. On the 19th of April the prisoner came to my shop - he looked at some waistcoats, and went out suddenly; when he had been gone about five minutes I missed one; he was stopped in the Back-road, and this waistcoat was found under his jacket; he said he had bought it - I said he had not paid for it.

Prisoner. He pulled me in - I know nothing about it; I told him I had no money; I had got a drop of a rum in my head. Witness. He looked at thirteen or fourteen - I first showed him some light ones, this was one of them; he then said he wanted a working waistcoat, and I showed him a blue one - he did not buy any.

GUILTY . Aged 37. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1320.
FRANCIS O'BRYAN
and
THOMAS McMAHONEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Oliver
, from his person; and that McMahoney had been before convicted of felony .

THOMAS OLIVER. On the 15th of April I was in Riding-house-yard
, between four and five o'clock - I had a handkerchief in my pocket; I felt it go from me; I turned - the prisoners and another boy were close behind me; the officer took them; McMahoney had my handkerchief.

THOMAS HOBBS (Police-constable C 85). I saw the two prisoners follow the prosecutor, and McMahoney took the handkerchief out of his pocket - the other prisoner, and another boy, who got away, were close to him - I had watched them all three in company.

CHARLES LANKINHORN
. I produce a certificate of the conviction of McMahoney, on the 5th of April, for stealing a handkerchief - he was whipped and discharged; I know he is the person.

O'BRYAN -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

MCMAHONEY -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .

1321.
WILLIAM PERKINS
and
JOHN TREGONIN
were indicted for
breaking and entering a building within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
John Leach Panter
, on the 9th of May , at Finchley
, and stealing therein 1 leg of mutton, value 4s.; 14 lbs. weight of beef, value 5s.; 1 tongue, value 2s.; 5 lbs, weight of veal, value 3s.; 1th. weight of bacon, value 6d.; 3 lbs. weight of cheese, value 1s. 6d., and 3 loaves of bread, value 1s., his property .

ELIZABETH ASSA
. I am in the service of Mr.
John Leach Panter
- he lives at Finchley. On the night of the 9th of May the dairy was broken open; I had seen it locked up at ten o'clock the night before; it was in the yard, but did not join the house; it was enclosed - I went there at a quarter before six in the morning; I found the door had been burst open, and the lock broken - I missed all the articles stated, which the officer afterwards produced - I do not know the prisoners.

ALFRED HARRIS
(Police-constable N 100). I was on duty on the morning of the 9th of May; I saw the two prisoners rather more than five miles from the prosecutor's - they were coming towards London, walking by a haycart; I did not know them, but in consequence of whatthe driver of the cart said, I felt it my duty to take them, and on the top of the hay I found this property.

ARCHER LEE
. I am a Police-constable. I was with Harris - what he states is correct.

JOSEPH WALLIS. I am servant to Mr. Roberts, a farmer, at South Mimms. I was coming to town with the bay-cart, and saw the prisoners coming up the Archway-road, about four miles from Finchley; they said, "Will you let us hand our basket behind your cart;" I said,"You may put it on the top, if you like," and they did so- I told the officer; I had seen them before - the basket contained this property.
Tregonin. I did not ask about putting it up. Witness. Yes, you both did.
ELIZABETH ASSA. This is the tongue; it is my master's, and so was the other property.
Perkins' Defence. I have been brought up respectably, but have met with great difficulties - Tregonin knows nothing about it, if I die for saying it.
Tregonin's Defence. I went out bird's-nesting, and saw this man, who asked me to carry a basket for him; we overtook this man with the hay-cart, and he asked him to let us put it behind.

PERKINS -
GUILTY . Aged 45.

TREGONIN -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Life .

1322.
ROBERT ROE
was indicted for
embezzlement .

WILLIAM BATE
. I am a baker . The prisoner was in my service for five or six weeks - he received money , and should account for it when he came home; he never accounted to me for 3l. 1s. 1 1/2d., on the 24th of April, received of Mr. Mitchell; he said he had not paid him, but he was coming that night to pay me.

ROBERT MITCHELL. I am in the First Regiment of Guards - my wife sells bread in the mews; I take it of the prosecutor. I paid the prisoners 3l. 1s. 2d. on the 24th of April - here is the bill and receipt for it.
MR. BATE. This is a week's bill - the prisoner ran away after he came home.

GUILTY . - Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
OLD COURT. TUESDAY, May 22.
First London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1323.
PATRICK LEARY
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .
MR. SCARLETT conducted the prosecution.

REBECCA CHRISTY
. I am the wife of
James Christy
- we keep the Robin Hood, in Shoe-lane
. On Saturday, the 14th of April , between five and six o'clock in the evening, the prisoner and another man came for a quartern of gin, which came to 4d.; I received a crown-piece from one of them, for which I gave change, and in about ten minutes discovered it to be counterfeit; I had no other in the house- the prisoner came again on Monday, alone, between five and six o'clock, and had half a pint of beer - I was at tea in the parlour; he gave 6d. to Fletcher, who called to me for changed - he gave me the 6d.; I took it to my husband in the parlour - he sent for a constable, who took the prisoner; I gave the officer the same sixpence and crown, after marking them.

WILLIAM FLETCHER
. I am Christy's servant. On the 16th of April I served the prisoner with porter, which came to 1d.; he gave me a sixpence, which I gave mistress I had seen him there on Saturday.

JAMES CHRISTY
. I keep this house. My wife gave me the sixpence; I went to the bar, and sent for a constable, to whom I gave the sixpence; it was not out of my sight at all - I marked it.

GEORGE CHIDZEY
. I am a constable. I was fetched to the house, and took the prisoner; I found 5d. in copper on him - somebody said he had dropped something, and I found a half-crown close to where he stood, near the bar; I had searched him before that - he said he had been to a public-house before, and tendered the six pence; they said it was bad, but he did not believe them, and for that reason tendered it here; I received a crown from Christy; persons going to the tap-room would not pass where I found the half-crown.
MRS. CHRISTY. This is the crown-piece I received on Saturday - it has my mark on it.

JOHN CHRISTY
. This is the sixpence my wife delivered to me - I marked it.

JOHN WOLVERIDGE
. I keep the Gentleman and Porter public-house, in New-street-square. On the 16th of April, about half-past four or five o'clock, the prisoner came for half a pint of beer, which I drew, and he threw down a sixpence - I returned it to him, saying it was a very had one; he said, "I am very sorry - I cannot have the porter."

JOHN FIELD
. I am an inspector of coin. This sixpence is counterfeit, and made of Britannia metal, so is the half-crown.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to the gentleman's house; he said the sixpence was bad - I had but 5d. more out of my wages; I worked that day at Mr. Johnson's - I was not satisfied to lose the sixpence; as I sounded it on the pavement a constable or man came up, and asked if I picked it up - I said No, but it had been refused; he said he should he glad of one hundred of them - I then went to this house to try it.
GUILTY .

Confined Six Months , and to
find Sureties .
NEW COURT. TUESDAY. MAY 22.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1324.
WILLIAM WEBSTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of May , 1 saddle, value 8s.; 2 girths, value 2s.; 1 pair of stirrup-leathers, value 3s., and 1 pair of stirrup-irons, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Benjamin Warden
, his master . - To which he
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Three Months .

1325.
SAMUEL BISS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of April , 1 watch, value 3l. , the goods of
William Reeve
. - To which he
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Three Months .

1326.
ROBERT MULLETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May , 1 wooden bowl, value 3d., and 92 farthings , the property of
Thomas Tilley
; to which he
pleaded GUILTY .
Confined Fourteen Days and
Whipped .

1327.
THOMAS HALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of April , 2 table-spoons, value 30s. , the goods of
Henry Richard Elsworth
. - To which he
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Nine Months .

1328.
JOHN WILLIAM HARTAM
was indicted for that
he, on the 27th of April , did forge a certain order for the delivery of goods , which is as follows:-
To the Directors of the West India Dock Company.
GENTLEMEN, - Please to deliver to order of Mr. Charles Kendall, nine hundred coker-nuts, ex Othello, under my command, from Honduras, entered by Pickstock, 24th of April, 1832.

JOHN BISHOP
, Master and Consignee. with intent to defraud
John Bishop
; against the Statute,& c.
FIVE OTHER COUNTS, varying the manner of laying the charge.

CHARLES KENDALL. I am a Custom-house agent, and live at York-terrace, Stepney. The prisoner was introduced to me about the 27th of April, by Mr. William Hallett, who said he was captain of the Othello, or words to that effect, and that he had some cokernuts to sell; I told him if he had coker-nuts to sell, I would give him the best price for them, and I would go on board the following morning or the morning after, and look at them - I went the next morning but one, and saw the prisoner, who appeared in treaty with another person; I agreed to purchase the coker-nuts at 17s. a hundred - I came round to the baggage-warehouse with him, where I saw my clerk, and I left him to close the transaction.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Is Mr. Hallett here? A. Not that I am aware of; he introduced the prisoner as master or captain - we have but one meaning for those words in the merchant service; Mr. Hallett is a Custom-house agent - I saw him some days ago; the prisoner speaks English, but I observed he was a foreigner; I think I saw Mr. Hallett at the Police-office.

THOMAS PICKSTOCK
. I am a merchant, and live in Nicholas-lane. I have the bills of lading; the prisoner was acquainted with the captain, who is not here - he was employed by the captain to sell those coker-nuts; I believe, on my oath, that he has acted as an innocent man, under the authority of the captain.
NOT GUILTY .

1329.
ELLEN REED
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of April , 1 gown, value 1s. 6d.; 6 spoons, value 20s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 2s. , the goods of
Robert Cussen
.

ROBERT CUSSEN. I keep a chandler's shop in Robin Hood-lane, Poplar
. The prisoner lodged at my house by the name of Mrs. Fisher, with a person who either was or passed as her husband - she left us on the 20th of March, and left some goods there; on the 10th of April she came again, and asked to be allowed to go to the room which she had occupied, and I went with her - it was then about half-past five o'clock; I had six silver tea-spoons laying on a table in that room - I saw them distinctly; I left her in the room about ten minutes; she then came down and went out; in about an hour I went to the room again, and missed the spoons - there was nobody in the house but me; my wife afterwards told me her gown was gone, and on the same day I missed a pair of trousers.

MICHAEL DRISCOLL
(Police-constable H 133.) In consequence of information I went to a house in Gloucester-row, Chelsea; I found the prisoner in a lodging there - this gown was laying on the bed-post; I asked if it was not Mrs. Cussen's - she said it was; I took her and told her she was accused of stealing six tea-spoons and a pair of trousers - she denied all knowledge of them, but said Mrs. Cussen gave her the gown.

SUSANNAH CUSSEN. I am the prosecutor's wife. This is my gown - I never lent it, sold it, or gave it to the prisoner - I had it in my own bed-room a fortnight before she quitted; and five or six days after St. Patrick's-day I missed it.

Prisoner. She gave it me when I was going to an Irish club. Witness. No, I never gave it - she never wore it in my presence - I am quite sure I never gave her authority to wear it; our street door was open in the day time - I do not know that another person might not have gone in, and taken the spoons; they have never been found.
Prisoner. I have witnesses to prove that I wore this gown in her house before her and her husband.

ROBERT CUSSEN. Their furniture is left there, and is, I believe, worth from 25s. to 30s. - she owed me 6l. 5s.; she did not offer to pay two sovereigns, nor did the man; I never saw her wear this gown.
Witness for the Defence.

MARY SULLIVAN. I lodged in the prosecutor's house for ten months, and never saw a silver spoon there - the prisoner lived there at the time; I saw this gown new upon Mrs. Cussen, and I afterwards saw it on the prisoner - upon my soleman oath I saw the prisoner wearing this gown for two months, while she was a lodger there.

MARGARET DONOHUE. I live at Blackwall. I have been in and out at the prosecutor's for three months in the last winter - I saw the prisoner twice with this gown on, in the presence of the prosecutor and his wife.
ROBERT CUSSEN. Sullivan left my house on the 17th of December - she had owed me a debt, which I got of her, and she has not been in my house since - Donohue has been there, but very seldom.

SUSANNAH CUSSEN
. The prisoner left me three days after St. Patrick's-day - I saw my gown safe a fortnight before she left.

MARY SULLIVAN
re-examined. Q. Upon your oath have you been into the prosecutor's house since the first day of the year? A. No, but I have seen the prisoner wearing the gown both in and out of the house - I live close by.
CATHERINE DRISCOLL. I used to go to the prosecutor's house to see their baby - I have seen the prisoner wear this gown; I am sure it is the same - I saw it on Mrs. Cussen's back when it was new.
NOT GUILTY .

1330.
JOHN CASHMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of May , 1 silver spoon, value 5s. , the goods of
John Thurlow
.

SIMON WESTLAKE
. I keep the Horse Shoe, in Titchbourne-street
. On the 17th of May I saw a ladder placed against a house opposite to mine, by the prisoner - the proprietor of the house came out, spoke to him, and went in again - the prisoner then ascended the ladder, went on tothe next house (No. 11), lifted up the window, went in, and returned in about a minute; I saw he was putting something into his pocket - he came down, took the ladder, and went away; I told the prosecutor of it.

THOMAS THURLOW
. I am the son of
John Thurlow
- we live at No. 11. In consequence of what Westlake said I went in pursuit of the prisoner, and came up with him in Coventry-street - he put down the ladder in Cox-court, and was about to descend into a cellar - I collared him, and this spoon, which is my father's, was produced to me by
Joseph Simms
, the proprietor of the One Tun.

MARY SHADWELL. I was standing near the cellar-flap, and saw the prisoner put the ladder down - he was going down himself, when Mr. Thurlow seized him - he pulled a spoon from under his jacket; I saw Mr. Simms take it from where he shifted it to, and give it to Mr. Thurlow - this is it.
FREDERICK CULLIMORE (Police-constable C 143). I took the prisoner, and have the spoon.
Prisoner. I was very much distressed - I meant to return it.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1331.
HENRY SAMPSON
and
WILLIAM HAYNES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Gotobed
, from his person .

THOMAS GOTOBED
. I live in Russell-street, Bloomsbury. On the afternoon of the 4th of May I was walking down Gate-street, Lincoln's Inn-fields
; a person touched my coat pocket; I turned, and saw the two prisoners in custody of Goldstone - Sampson had my handkerchief concealed in his jacket; he gave it me himself - I delivered it to the officer.

JAMES GOLDSTONE
. I am an umbrella-maker, and live in Gate-street. On the 4th of May I was in my shop, and saw the prosecutor pass, followed by the prisoners -I saw Haynes lift up the prosecutor's pocket; I left my shop to go and caution him, but before I got to him Haynes took the handkerchief, and gave it to Sampson; I took them both - by my direction Sampson gave up the handkerchief.
JOHN GALLAHER. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoners.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

SAMPSON -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

HAYNES -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1332.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of May , 2 hats, value 26s. , the goods of
Samuel Dutton
.

SAMUEL DUTTON. I live on Ludgate-hill
, and am a hatter . I know nothing of the prisoner, but I lost these hats from my shop.

JOHN KIRKMAN (Police-constable F 107). I took the prisoner carrying these two hats in the Strand, on the 2nd of May; I asked how he got them; he said they belonged to him - I asked what was the initials on them; he declined to tell me; I took him a little way; he made a bolt, and ran; I took him again, and took him to the station - I found this model of a key upon him.

PETER GEORGE HASE. I am a shoemaker. I was going down Ludgate-hill - I saw the prisoner and a respectably dressed young man; I had seen them in bad company, and I followed them; when we were opposite to Rundell and Bridge's I missed the other; I waited a few minutes, and saw the prisoner go into the prosecutor's shop, and come out with these hats - I followed him to the Straud, and told the officer, who took him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 32 -
Transported for Seven Years .

1333.
JAMES SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of May , 1 whip, value 4s. , the goods of
Arthur Williams
.

ARTHUR WILLIAMS
. I drive a beer-dray , and live in Wood's-place, Bowling-green-lane. On the 8th of May I left my dray in Tavistock-square
; I put my whip against some rails while I delivered some beer; when I came back, I missed the whip - I saw the prisoner at a distance; he threw the whip out of his hand; my fellow-servant pursued; I went round, and met him - this is my whip; I am sure he is the person.

THOMAS GOODVER
(Police-constable E 39). I took the prisoner, and produce the whip.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, pleading poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 52. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1334.
FREDERICK TERRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of April , 2 half-crowns, and 1 shilling, the monies of
John Auden
, from his person .

JOHN AUDEN. I live with my father, in Homer-street. On the 23rd of April I was sitting at a table in Chalk Farm tea-gardens
; I put some silver into my coat pocket - I saw the prisoner sitting at a table, on a form; I thought I felt his hand in my pocket; I felt, and my money was gone - I waited to see what he would do; when he was leaving the garden I accused him of it; he said he had not a farthing about him - he was searched, and two half-crowns found on him; I thought at first he did it for a joke - I had tossed with him for a glass of brandy and water, and a pint of ale.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How many persons were there? A. I think there were four females; two of them were named Cohen; I do not know the other's name - O yes, I forgot, one of them was named Mitchell; I do not recollect any other female who had been in my company that night - I do not know a girl named Reeves; I have seen the prisoner two or three times, but had no acquaintance with him - I had been in his company accidentally; I have met him at Mr. McDonald's concert-room, in Portland-street, and may have joked with him; I do not recollect saying to
Mary Ann Mitchell
that she had no need to fear any thing about a subposna, and she had better not come here - I could almost say No.

Q. Now, do you not know that you told her she had better not come here, and that she had no need to care for a subpoena, as it would not be enforced? A. I was at the Yorkshire Stingo last Sunday evening; she there told me that she had to come here - I asked what it was, she said to appear; that was all I said; I may have seen her ten times at McDonald's; she did not tell me from whom the subpoena came, nor what trial it was on Sunday, but I had heard her say at McDonald's that shehad to appear here - I do not think I told her she had no need to come; the prisoner did not say that it was true enough he had some money of mine, but he should keep it for a treat - my money did not fall out; there had not been a great deal of larking - we had brandy and water, and ale; I paid for some; I think the prisoner paid 6d., and Mitchell paid 6d.

JOHN TISDALR
. I am a constable. I was going up to Chalk Farm a little after seven o'clock in the evening of the 23rd of April; I saw a mob - the prisoner was sitting on a grass plot, and the prosecutor standing by, asking him for his money - the prisoner made use of very bad language, and swore he had not got a farthing about him; I took off his shoes, and found in his stockings two half-crowns, which I took through some boles; he made a great deal of resistance - when I found the money he said he was very sorry, and wanted the prosecutor to forgive him; he said he would give him 1l. - he said he knew he should be transported, and it would be a good job for him.

Cross-examined. Q.Do you remember his saying he did not intend to steal it? A. I did not hear that; I recollect his telling the prosecutor they were all friends together - I did not notice any girls there.

JOHN GAYTON JOLLY (Police-constable S 164). I was on duty near Chalk Farm gardens - I saw the prisoner in custody of Tisdale; I assisted to take him to the watch-house - I said to him, "Don't you think you are a pretty sort of a fellow, to sit with a friend and rob him?" he said,"I did rob him, and it would be the best thing for him and for me to be transported."
Witnesses for the Defence.

MARY ANN
MITCHELL. I live in Frederick-place, Hampstead-road. On the 23rd of April I was at Chalk Farm, with the prosecutor and the prisoner; I had seen the prosecutor before - I went across the gardens to speak to a friend, and saw the prisoner and him quarrelling - I asked what it was about; the prosecutor said he had lost 7s. out of his pocket, and he could not accuse any one but the prisoner; the prisoner was very much intoxicated, and could not say much to him, but kept walking round and round - we had a good deal to drink; I saw the prosecutor at the Yorkshire Stingo on Sunday week, and on last Sunday; I said I was subpoenaed to come here - he said I had no call to come without I liked, but he did not say why; I had seen him a good many times at Mr. Donald's
COURT. Q. Did you see the money found? A. No, I did not notice that - I considered it might be done out of a joke; I did not hear the prisoner deny having it.

ELLEN SCOTT
. I live in Portland-street. I have known the prosecutor and the prisoner some time - I was at Chalk Farm on the 23rd of April; I saw the prosecutor, the prisoner, and several others romping on the grass; the form was knocked over; the prosecutor said he had lost 7s., but he could not blame any body but the prisoner; I did not hear him say he found his hand in his pocket; I thought they were friends.

COURT. Q.What are you? A. A servant out of place - I went to Chalk Farm that day, being Easter Monday.
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1335.
WILLIAM WARE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 1 saw, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Capps
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

THOMAS CAPPS
. I am a pawnbroker , and live in Old-street-road
. On the 24th of March I missed a small brass-backed saw from a stall in front of my house - I had seen it safe half an hour before; it has not been found since - we had a young man to mind the property, but he turned his back for a moment.

JOSEPH ROBINS
. I live opposite the prosecutor. I was at my door a little after nine o'clock in the morning; I saw a person, who has been convicted, take the saw from the board - he gave it to the prisoner, who gave it to another person.
WILLIAM ROBINS. I saw Porfleet, who has been convicted, take the saw and give it to the prisoner, and they all moved off together.

ROBERT LOVELOCK
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner in Wilderness-row - he denied all knowledge of it.
CHARLES WALLER. I am a Police-constable. I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office - I was present, and know he is the person - (read.)

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1336.
GEORGE WILD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
George Gallop
, from his person .

GEORGE GALLOP
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Berwick-street, Soho. I was walking in Old-street
on the 13th of April, between one and two o'clock; I thought I felt something - I put my hand down, and my handkerchief was gone; I saw the prisoner rolling it up, and putting it into his bosom - I took hold of him, and gave him into custody; he said, "It is not yours."

JAMES BUCKLE
. I am an officer; I received the prisoner in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1337.
ANN WALKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 4 lbs, weight of cheese, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Francis Bateman
; and that she had been before convicted of felony .

MATTHEW BATEMAN. I am in the service of
Francis Bateman
- he keeps a shop in Theobald's-road
. On the evening of the 28th of April I saw the prisoner come to the shop; she did not buy any thing - I missed some cheese from the window; I followed her - I saw something under her shawl; she gave it into another woman's apron; the other woman turned up a mews, and threw the cheese down, saying she did not want it - the prisoner followed her; I kept close to her; I called my brother, and she was taken - this is the cheese; here are 41bs. of it.

CHARLES NORMAN
(Police-constable 48E). I took the prisoner from the witness, and have the cheese.
THOMAS REED (Police-constable C 159). I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office - I know she is the person - (read.)
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Confined Seven Days .

1338
FANNY BURR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of May , 9 sovereigns, the monies of
John Christie
, from his person .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecutions.

JOHN CHRISTIE. I was a shopkeeper , but have retired, and live in George-street, Lambeth. On the 7th of May I had been dining with some friends; I had been drinking all day, and was going home at past one o'clock in the morning - I had a little terrier dog with me; I was very heavy with liquor, and rather sleepy - I observed a woman pick the dog up; I consider it was near Charing-cross - she kept walking on; I followed her into a house in Whitcomb-street
; I remember going into a room, but after that I remember no more till I was awoke; I had not picked up the woman, or made any advances to her; I had a watch, and nine sovereigns in gold, in my fob, loose, under my watch; I consider that I fell asleep immediately - I was awoke by a woman, but I cannot say who it was; she asked me something; I felt for my watch, and found my fob was turned inside out - I believe I sat still, but I hardly know; I then heard a person's voice say."Here, here, take your watch," and it was quietly put into my hand; upon this, a Policeman came up - the prisoner was then present; the Policeman asked if I had lost any thing; I said, Yes, ten or twelve sovereigns, and my watch, but the woman had given me my watch back - I went to the Police station - I fell asleep till the morning - I then went before the Magistrate, and gave my evidence; I can recollect as late as twelve o'clock at night, that I had ten sovereigns in my watch-fob, and I took out one, and changed it; I had changed two in the course of the day; from twelve o'clock till one I had been at a public-house in Jermyn-street.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Is this house one that you know? A. I lived so long in the neighbourhood I cannot say I do not know the street, there are several brothels in that street; I had never been in that house, to my knowledge, before; the dog caused me to go there - I know I had my money at twelve o'clock, when I got change for a sovereign - I then took out my watch, and felt the rest of my money there; my sovereigns could not fall out - my fob is very narrow - I swear I had nine sovereigns at twelve o'clock at night; in the morning, when I came from Lambeth to town, I know perfectly well I had twelve sovereigns in my watch fob; I changed no more than three - I had been drinking all day; I can drink a good deal sometimes - I had part of two bottles of wine between three of us before breakfast; I had wine and water at different houses- I think I was in four houses - I drank no beer; I might take ale, or a glass of rum and water - after two o'clock I became very much intoxicated; I took two glasses of rum and water with a friend in Jermyn-street, and do not recollect what took place after that.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you know the prisoner before? A.No.

ANN BARRETT. I am servant at the house, No. 18, Whitcomb-street. The prisoner did not lodge there, but on the 8th of May she came there, about half-past one o'clock in the morning; she had a dog in her arms - the prosecutor followed her, and asked for the dog; she was going up stairs - I told her the prosecutor was in liquor; she said he was not in liquor, but near sighted - they then went up stairs, and were there for an hour or an hour and a half; I then heard a creaking on the stairs - I went out of the parlour, and saw the prisoner coming down the last flight of stairs, with her shoes in her hand; I asked where the gentleman was - she said he was up stairs, that he had but 2s. about him, and she would not stop with him; I told her to go up stairs - I followed her with a candle; when I went into the room I found the prosecutor leaning back on the sofa, with his hat under the stove, and his fobpocket turned inside out, which was not so when he went in; I said to the prisoner,

"I don't think it is all right;" she said she knew the prosecutor, that he was a horse-dealer, and lived in Tothill-street - I shook the prosecutor, and awoke him; the prisoner was standing by - I told him she had been leaving the house without her shoes, and I had detained her; he put his hand to his fob, and said he had lost his watch - I then came down to call a Policeman, but my husband had called one, and he went up with him; the prisoner had fastened the room door - the Policeman knocked, and she opened the door; there was then a sovereign and two halfpence on the table, which had not been there just before - and the prosecutor was sitting at the foot of the bed, with his watch in his hand; he told us the woman had given him the watch back - the officer then asked him if he had lost any thing; he said he had lost ten or twelve sovereigns - the prisoner declared she had not more than half a crown or two shillings about her, and wished to be searched in the house; the prosecutor and the prisoner were then taken to St. Ann's watch-house - the prosecutor seemed very much in liquor, and more so when I went up to awake him than before.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you married? A. Yes, and I live servant there; there was no one in the house but the prosecutor, the prisoner, I, my husband, and my master.

WILLIAM BARRETT. I am the husband of this witness. I saw the prisoner come in about half-past one o'clock, with a dog in her arms; she went up stairs, and the prosecutor went up after her - I heard her say to him on the stairs,"Do you mean to stop all night or not?" he said,

"No, I want my dog;" they went up stairs, and I heard no more for some time; I then heard some footsteps coming down stairs very slow and very light - I came out of the room, and saw the prisoner with her shoes in her hand; my wife stopped her; I went for the Policeman, and went up stairs with him - he knocked at the door, and sang out"Police - if you don't open the door I will;" I went in, and saw the prosecutor sitting on the bed, with his watch in his hand, and his fob turned out; there was a sovereign and two halfpence on the table - the prisoner said she had nothing about her whatever, and the Policeman took her in charge.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you or your wife go out first when you heard the prisoner? A.We both went out together - she denied that she had any money of the prosecutor's.

COURT. Q. Give us her words? A. I asked the prosecutor if he had lost any money, and he said, Yes, ten or twelve sovereigns; the prisoner said she had no money belonging to him, and that she had no money at all about her - I and my wife were sitting in the back parlour when she came down - I went for the Policeman; my wife did not go out of the street door.

WILLIAM TURNER (Police-constable C 176.) I wascalled into the house by
William Barrett
- we went up stairs; the room door was fast - I knocked and called out Police! I heard a lock or a bolt move; I then opened the door, which I could not do before, and went in - I saw the prosecutor sitting on the foot of the bed; I said,
"What is the matter, old boy?" and tapped him on the shoulder; I saw he was very tipsy - he said,

"I have lost my watch and my sovereigns;" I said, "You have your watch in your hand" - he said, "She gave it me back;" I said,"How many sovereigns have you lost?" he said ten or twelve - the prisoner said,
"I have no money belonging to him;" I said,
"Here is a sovereign on the table" - she said, "I would not submit to him for a sovereign;" I said,
"You are very extravagant, I will take this and put it into my pocket - come, turn it up, or I will take you to the station;" she said,

"Search me here" - I said, "No, I will take you to the station;" we went there - I said to the inspector, "The old gentleman is not quite compos mentis, but he tells his story so straight forward that I wish to search the prisoner;" I took a candle and went into a private cell, where I stripped the prisoner to her shift, stockings, and shoes - two sovereigns fell from her bosom, and she said,

"They were given me by a gentleman I met in the Haymarket;" she then said I was a very good lady's maid, and asked me to dress her again - I said I would do my best; she said, "You have found nothing," but I told her to sit down, and I took off one of her shoes - she again said, "You have found nothing," but I took off the other, and found these six sovereigns in it.
Cross-examined. Q.Have you not a woman for the purpose of examining females? A.No; the prisoner made no charge against the prosecutor; she said she had no money belonging to him, and no money at all.

Prisoner's Defence. They did not ask me if I had any money, only if I had robbed the prosecutor; I told them I had not - I had met him that night near Charing-cross; he asked me to take him home, and I said I could not; he then asked me if I knew a house; I took him to Whitcomb-street - he said he was afraid of losing his dog - I said I would take that; he told me to go on, and he would follow me; we went to a back room, for which he paid 1s. - he gave me two sovereigns, which I put into my bosom; he then wanted to take improper liberties with me - I was an hour and a half before I could get away; I was going down, and met the witness on the stairs; she said, "Where is your friend;" I said,

"He is up stairs;" he had sat down, and pretended to be asleep - the officer was fetched, and I was taken to the station; the next day he did not know what to say; he at first said it was at half-past two o'clock, then at three, and then between eleven and twelve; the officer told him what to say.
ANN BARRETT re-examined. Q.Had the prosecutor paid 1s. for the room? A. Yes, he certainly had; she forced the 1s. out of his pocket, and he said, "I want my dog, I want to go home."

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1339.
WILLIAM JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of April
, 1 Bible, value 15s. , the goods of
John Stenson
.

THOMAS HENRY PARKER
. I live at my father-in-law's shop, in Princes-street, Soho
; he is a bookseller . On Wednesday evening the 18th of April, a person came in very like the prisoner, in a blue cloak, like the one here produced; he asked for a Tasso, or some such book which he had seen at our house - I told him we had no such book; I had observed a Bible on the counter that day - he said he would call again the next morning; I saw the Bible which had been on our counter at Mr. Barron's on the Tuesday following - this is it; it has our mark on it; I had not sold it - it is worth 15s.

Prisoner. This witness said at the office that he did not recognize me in the slightest degree; he was urged by the Police-officer to say that I was the man, and that I was well known - and then he said I was something like the thief. Witness. I said I did not recollect your face exactly; I had not seen the cloak produced before I saw you - I said before I recollected, that it was on Wednesday or Thursday, but I afterwards recollected it was Wednesday, two days before Good Friday. I did not say it was a wet evening, and that the prisoner was muffled up in a cloak; I said he had a cloak on - it was between eight and nine o'clock, as near as I can recollect; it was dark; the shop was not very well lighted; you was not there many minutes; there was no other person present - I missed the Bible in about half an hour - I do not recollect selling you a book about a fortnight before; I cannot recollect your face now, but your voice is similar - the Bible has a mark in it, but some dirt has been rubbed over it.

JAMES BARRON. I live in Drury-lane, and keep a general sale shop.
