On Wednesday evening, the 18th of April, the prisoner came in; he had a blue cloth coat and spectacles on; he was very smartly dressed, and his cloak enveloped him completely; the prisoner is the man, I recollect his person perfectly well - he came about ten minutes or a quarter-past nine o'clock; he said, "Is this a pawnbroker's?" I said "No, it is not;" he said, "I have a book I want to raise some money on," and he asked if I would buy it; I said I did not care; he showed me this Bible, said it was valuable, and had the Apocrypha - he wanted 10s. on it - I gave him 8s. for it, and I said if he wanted it again he should have it; he pressed very much upon me to keep it for him; I put it in the window the next day - I particularly noticed his voice, he has rather a foreign accent and I recognized him by that; Mr. Parker came and asked for the book, and knew it by the mark; the prisoner came again on the Tuesday evening following, with a brush; I had received information to detain him; I made sure he was the man, and I called my wife to be sure that he was the person - she said Yes; I have not the slightest doubt by his voice and appearance that he is the man - this is the Bible; it had a private mark in it, which had been rubbed when I had it from the prisoner; I think my shop is three-quarters of a mile from the prosecutor's.

THOMAS WRAY
(Police-constable F 31). I was called into Mr. Barron's shop, to take the prisoner; he had a blue coat and silver spectacles; he had a crape hat-band on, but he took it off in the station-house, while I went for Miss Roberts.
Prisoner. When you returned you said I had taken off the crape, which I had rolled up, that it might resume a smooth shape - I did it from no sinister motive.

THOMAS HENRY PARKER
. I have not the slightestdoubt that this book is ours - we had exactly such a one; I did not observe whether the prisoner had spectacles on, he had a black hat.

Prisoner. During the whole of the evening I was in the company of a young gentleman whose mother is present, but I am told he is not at present to be found; I returned to my apartments at ten o'clock, and left them at four o'clock, I was never from the society nor from the arm of that person; in the deposition Barron distincly swore the Bible was sold to him on the Thursday, and it would have been impossible for me to have known whether it was a valuable one, and whether it had the Apocrypha or not in it, if I had it so short a time.
GUILTY . Aged 32.

1340. WILLIAM JOHNSON was again indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of April
, 1 hat-brush, value 2s. , the goods of
William Roberts
.

JAMES BARRON
. The prisoner came to my house on the 24th of April with this brush - he was dressed in black and had a blue cloak on his arm, and his spectacles as before - I looked at him, as I had received information but half an hour before - I said to him,

"You sold me a book?" he said, "I did;" I said, "I have had information, and I must detain you;" he said, "For God's sake, don't do that, I shall be ruined;" I said, "I must do my duty;" I sent my servant for an officer, but Wray was going by, and he took him - I looked at the brush, but did not particularly observe it.

ELIZABETH ROBERTS. I live with my father,
William Roberts
- he lives in St. Martin's-court
, and is a brush-maker . On the 24th of April a man came into our shop, and asked to look at a clothes-brush; I took out the drawer- he said he wanted one with a handle; I turned, and got one out of the window - he said the hairs were not long enough; I said we had no longer, and he went out - we had several brushes on a tray in the shop; I did not miss one, but I have seen the one produced - it has my father's name on it, and had been in our shop; it is worth 3s. - I had not sold such a brush on the 24th of April - the person had a cloak on his arm, a stick in his hand, and a crape hat-band - I did not observe his face or his voice; it was between six and seven o'clock in the evening.

THOMAS WRAY. I am the officer. I took the prisoner about nine o'clock in Mr. Barron's shop - I took the brush from his hand at the station; he had this cloak and this stick - I do not know whether he had any spectacles on, as I did not like to take hold of him - I thought he was certainly a nobleman; he then had whiskers, and his hair was all about his forehead, but he was shaved his whiskers off.
Prisoner. I have a witness that I bought that brush in the beginning of Passion-week, in St. Martin's-court - I believe it was of Miss Roberts herself, though it was only the affair of a moment.

ELIZABETH HASLET. I live in White Lion-street, Pentonville - the prisoner lodged with me. I know he had a brush of this kind - he showed it to me, and said he gave 2s. 9d. for it; he lived with me five or six weeks - I cannot say when I first saw the brush, nor when I last saw it- it was a small hat-brush.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1341.
RICHARD GIBBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of May , 1 bottle, value 3d., and 1 pint of rum, value 2s. , the goods of
Charles Temple
.

ALGERNON SMITH
(Police-constable S 22). On the night of the 7th of May I stopped the prisoner in Skinner-street, with this bottle under his coat; he appeared partly intoxicated - I asked where he got it - he said he bought it of a boy for 4d., at the corner of Brill-row.

CHARLES TEMPLE. I keep the Somers'-town coffee-house, in Charlton-street
. I have lost two or three sample-bottles of spirits - this is one of mine, and had rum in it; it has the mark of the ship on it: it was safe on the Friday, when we cleaned the window.
Prisoner. He could not swear to it at the office. Witness. My young man could not swear to it, but when I went I could - he was taken nearly a quarter of a mile from my house.
JURY. Q. Are you satisfied that no other publican has such a private mark as you have? A. It is not my mark, it is the ship's mark, and my number, which is 63; the numbers go regularly.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1342.
JAMES EPPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of May , 1 fish-plate, value 2s. , the goods of
John Walden
.

ELIZABETH WALDEN
. I live with my father,
John Walden
, at Somers'-town
- he deals in china . I saw the prisoner outside the shop, on the morning of the 9th of May; he asked the price of something - I said I could not tell, as my mother was out; I then saw a fish-tray under his arm; I went and overtook him in Seymour-street, with it - he said he had bought it of a girl, but gave it to me; it is the same size and pattern as ours, and we missed one - it has no mark on it.

FREDERICK HILES
. I took the prisoner - he told me he bought the plate of a girl for 3d. - he did not say when.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought it in Petticoat-lane.
NOT GUILTY .

1343
HENRY COTTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Thomas Jackson
, from his person .

THOMAS JACKSON
. I live in George-street, Minories. On the 5th of May, about half-past ten o'clock at night, I was walking along; I felt something - I turned and missed my handkerchief; I saw the prisoner a few yards off, throwing it down - I pursued him, and he was stopped; I had not lost sight of him - this is it.

JOHN DAGLEY
(Police-constable G 171). I stopped the prisoner at the corner of Greville-street, Hatton-garden- I got this handkerchief from a young lady, in the prosecutor's presence: I saw the prisoner throw two handkerchiefs down, and I got another from him at the station.
Prisoner's Defence. I never had the prosecutor's handkerchief in my possession; I did not throw any away- the gentleman raised his umbrella to strike me, and I ran away.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1344.
WILLIAM DAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of May , 2 shillings, the monies of
Henry Vickress
, his master .

ELIZA GRIGGS
. I am in the service of Mr.
Henry Vickress
- he keeps the Pied Bull, in the Lower-road, Islington
- the prisoner is his porter . In consequence of something that occurred. I placed 20s. in silver in the till, which had been marked by Mr. Vickress, and given to me- a little after six o'clock in the morning on the 6th of May, the prisoner had been cleaning the bar, and I missed two shillings - when Mr. Vickress came down I told her of it; the officer was called, and these two shillings were found on him; I know they are two of the shillings which had been in the till - they have the marks on them.
GEORGE COLLIER (Police-constable N 94). I was called in, and took the prisoner - I found the two marked shillings in his waistcoat pocket.
HENRY VICKRESS. The prisoner was in my employ. -I marked these two shillings, and know them again.
The prisoner received a good character, and his master engaged to employ him again.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Confined Seven Days .

1345.
SARAH GOLDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of May , 2 pairs of gloves, value 1s.; 12 yards of quilling, value 7d.; 1 yard of ribbon, value 4d., and 3 yards of lace, value 2s. 9d. , the goods of
Richard Hall
and another.

CHARLES WARMALL. I am shopman to Richard Hall and another, linen-draper s, St. John-street
. On the 9th of May the prisoner came and bought some quilling net, gloves, and stockings, which came to 1s. 10d. - I saw her conceal these articles, which were worth 4s. 9d.; she handed them to her little boy, who is about seven years old, and he put them into her basket; she took them out and put them into her pocket - I let her go out, and as she passed the window I took her back; my master told her to give up what she had - she took them out and put them down.

CHARLES WRIGHT (Police-constable G 105). I received charge of the prisoner, and produce the articles, which were given to me by Mr. Freeman - the prisoner said her little boy took them, and she was not conscious of it.
Prisoner's Defence. The little boy put them in unknown to me.
NOT GUILTY .

1346.
JOSEPH HENLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of April , 2 pairs of callipers, value 3s.; 1 hammer, value 3s.; 1 fuller, value 1s. 6d., and 1 chisel, value 1s. , the goods of
James Wilmott
.

JAMES WILMOTT. I live in Hind-street, Hatton-wall
. I deal in tools , and am a smith - the prisoner was in my father's employ, and afterwards in mine for two years; he had my tools to work with, but was not to take them away- I missed two pairs of brass callipers, and some other tools; I spoke to the prisoner about them - he said another person, named Hudson, had taken them, whom I had employed two days in the week; I afterwards went to a house in St. Luke's, with an officer - I found the prisoner there, and these callipers in a tea-caddy, and under the bed I found this hammer, and this fuller - he said they were his; I can speak to these two pairs of callipers with certainty, as being mine; one of them is broken at one end, and the other overlaps.

Prisoner. I brought them up to town with me when his father sent for me - I worked for him seven years, and then for his widow, when this prosecutor turned her out of the house; and now he wants to get me out - he has reduced me to four days' work in a week; I used to live in the house. Witness. I had a spare room, and I let him have it - he said, when those things were found, that he brought them from the country; I cannot say any thing about the hammer and fuller, but I lost such things.

HENRY HUDSON. I work for the prosecutor. There were two pairs of callipers there, and this pair I can be certain of; I have known this these twelve years - this hammer I am certain of, the prisoner made it himself.

JOHN LEAVER
. I work for the prosecutor. I have known this hammer for eighteen months, and this fuller I can swear to by some marks on the neck of it - it is the prosecutor's; the prisoner knows that he made another a size larger, because this was too small for some work.
Prisoner. About four years ago this man was discharged for stealing a hammer, and I got him in. Witness. I was discharged, but I never knew what for.

SAMUEL FREEMAN. I have worked for the prosecutor, and have known the prisoner twelve months. A few weeks ago he came to do some work at my place; he brought some tools, and said they were for his use; he threw them down, and said he would b-y soon alter them; this gave me suspicion, and I told the prosecutor; the prisoner came one morning just as I opened my shop, and took the tools.

THOMAS MORRIS
(Police-constable G 27). I took the prisoner at a house in Little Mitchel-street - I found these articles there; he said they were his own.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the tools were his own - and that he had gone into business on his own account, which had caused this prosecution against him.

JAMES WILMOTT
. I believe he had gone into business.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1347.
MARY JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of May , 3 lbs. weight of pork, value 2s. , the goods of
James Pallet
.

EDWARD KING. I am servant to Mr.
James Pallet
, a cheesemonger , of Oxendon-street, Somers'-town
. On the 5th of May a customer told me this pork was taken; I pursued, and took the prisoner - she dropped it by her side.
SAMUEL HEYWOOD (Police-constable S 144). I took the prisoner - she asked me to forgive her.

GUILTY . Aged 66. -
Confined Seven Days .

1348.
JAMES THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of May , 4 loaves of bread, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William Martin
.

ROBERT HIGGINS
. I am in the service of Mr.
William Martin
, a baker , in Chancery-lane. I left my basket in Cursitor-street
; I was not absent two minutes - I turned, and saw the prisoner take four loaves out of it, and run away; I ran, and called Stop thief! he threw them down- I never lost sight of him till the officer took him.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1349.
JOHN THOMAS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of May , 2 boots, value 8s. , the goods of
Kerenhappuch Armstrong
.

ROBERT JOHN WICKS. These boots belong to Mrs.Kerenhappuch Armstrong - I was serving a customer, and saw the prisoner going from the shop, putting something under his coat - I looked over my board to see if he had taken a pair of boots which were there, but he had not; I pursued, but he got away; the officer afterwards brought him and these two boots, which I know are Mrs. Armstrong's - I am quite sure he is the man I saw going from the shop; I knew nothing of him before - I have the two fellow boots to them.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me in the shop? A. Yes, you were retreating from the shop - you came begging, and took them.

JOHN NEWTON (Police-constable E 32). I was on duty near the King's-cross, and saw the prisoner come running towards me - I stopped him, and asked what he had got; he said a pair of boots, which he was going to take to St. Giles'; I found those two odd boots - I went to Islington, and found the prosecutor.
Prisoner's Defence. A man I knew gave me them to mind for him.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1350.
SUSAN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of May , 9 stockings, value 2s.; 1 box-iron, value 1s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. , the goods of
Joseph Prince
.

FRANCES ELIZABETH PRINCE
. I go out charing; my husband's name is Joseph; I have known the prisoner for two years - I have employed her the last two months to take care of my children while I was out; I missed some odd stockings out of a box to which she had access - I spoke to her about them; she said she had taken them; I never allowed her to take them - I think she took the best of them; I told her if she would give me them back I would not hurt her - she told the officer where they were.
RICHARD COLLINS (Police-constable G 124). I went to a house in Playhouse-yard, by the prisoner's direction, and found these stockings and this box-iron.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. The stockings I sold.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1351.
WILLIAM ASPREY
and
WILLIAM EDWARDS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of May , 4 1bs. of lard, value 3s. , the goods of
William Pitt
.

SARAH WOOD. Mr.
William Pitt
keeps a butter-shop in Kingsland-road
. On the 4th of May, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoners loitering about his shop - I watched, and saw Edwards take a bladder of lard; Asprey stood on the other side of the shop - they ran off together; they did not go into the shop; I gave information, and they were taken with the lard - I am quite sure of their persons.

JOHN PITT
. Wood gave me information - I went out, and saw Asprey running; I took him - this lard was brought back, which is my father's.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am an officer. I was on duty, saw Asprey running from the shop, and took him into custody.
FILDER HARRIS (Police-constable N 228). I saw Asprey and another, who I believe was Edwards, standing near the prosecutor's shop - in a few minutes they were gone, and the lard likewise.

JOHN COLLINS
(Police-constable N 241). I took Edwards with the lard a quarter of a mile from the shop.

WILLIAM PITT
. I know this bladder of lard by a mark on it.

ASPREY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

EDWARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1352.
JAMES BRANGROVE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , 2 spoons, value 18s. , the goods of
Francis Gray
, Lord Gray in that part of the United Kingdom called Scotland .

JOSHUA BEALE
. I am in the employ of my father, who is a watchmaker, at Twickenham. The prisoner brought a dessert-spoon to us on the 21st or 23rd of May; as soon as I found whose it was, I took it to Lord Gray - he came again on the 25th, with part of a spoon, which I gave to the constable; I know the prisoner, and am sure he is the person - I had seen him several times.

RICHARD BEGEN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; I asked what he had done with the remainder of the spoon; he said, "Buried it in Mr. Williams' garden;" we went there, and found this part of the table-spoon.

SAMUEL PATTERSON
. I am butler to
Francis Gray
, Lord Gray; he lives at Twickenham
; the prisoner's mother was in his employ - I have seen the prisoner there; I know this property to be Lord Gray's,
Cross-examined. Q.What was his mother? A. She works in the garden, and sometimes comes into the kitchen- she may have taken them; the crest has not been erased.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Three Months .

1353.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the property of
Thomas Slater
, from his person .

THOMAS SLATER
. I am a cabinet-maker . I was at the corner of Great Queen-street
, at half-past eight o'clock, on the 6th of May - I did not feel my handkerchief taken, but the prisoner passed me - I saw my handkerchief in his hand; I pursued, and took him with it - this is it.

DANIEL HONE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going down Queen-street, behind this gentleman; his handkerchief fell down - he came and took me.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1354.
JOHN BRADBEAR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of April , 5 saws, value 23s., and 1 plane, value 3s., the goods of
Joseph Skinner
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

JOSEPH SKINNER
. I am a carpenter . The prisoner lodged with me in April - I went into the workshop when he left, and found three duplicates; I then looked over my tools, and missed a number of them; I had taken the prisoner in, and lodged him, and given him a few jobs, as he was in distress - he gave himself up to the officer.
Prisoner. Q.Whose tools had I when I worked for you? A.Some of mine were lent to you, but you returned them.

SMITH JOBSON TAYLOR (Police-constable C 111). On the night of the 20th of April, the prisoner came to me in Regent-street, and desired me to take him into custody; he said he had committed a robbery some days before, and taken three saws from Nassau-street - I went there, and found it was true; the next morning I went to the prosecutor, who gave me the duplicates.

JOHN GEORGE TEMPLE
. I am in the service of a pawnbroker; I took in one saw from the prisoner, I believe - and here is another I did not take in.(Property produced and sworn to.)
SMITH JOBSON TAYLOR. I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office.

JOSEPH SKINNER
, JUN. They were my saws and tools, which he took at that time.
Prisoner. You well know the tools I took at that time were not stolen; they laid on the bench week after week. Witness. They were for use, but not to be pawned.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1355.
JOHN CHAPMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of May , 1 tea-caddy, value 7s., the goods of
George Wilson
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

DORCAS CHAMBERLAIN. Mr. Wilson keeps a broker's-shop . About two o'clock on the 8th of May, I was looking out of my window; I saw the prisoner go and take the caddy and walk away with it - I called Stop thief! and he was taken with it; he had turned a corner, but I know he is the person.
WILLIAM BROWN. I am a green-grocer, and live near the prosecutor. I heard the alarm, and took the prisoner with this caddy under his arm, in Tavistock-place.
MARY WILSON. I am the wife of George Wilson. This is my caddy; I was at home, but did not see it taken.
JAMES FULLER. I am a Police-constable. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office; I know he is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1356.
FRANCIS SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , 1 spoon, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
James William Henry Faulkner
.

MARY FAULKNER. I am the wife of
James William Henry Faulkner
, a surgeon , at Pimlico
. The prisoner came there on the 16th of May, for one ounce of salts, and 2d. worth of assafoetida; I served him and he went away; I went up into the drawing-room; I then saw him come twice to the door and go away - he came a third time and then knocked; I went to him; he said he wanted double the quantity of each article; I said I could serve him with the salts, but I did not know where the other was - while I was doing that he said I must write a direction for him; there then came a knock at the door; he asked if he should answer; I said if he pleased; he went, and I heard him say No; he came in and said it was a young man who wanted to know if any cabinet-maker lived there; my husband then came in, and said the other young man had taken his coat from the hall - I said, "Take this one into custody," but the prisoner got out; I did not miss anything then, but the officer brought him back in about ten minutes, with this spoon.
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. When had you seen this spoon? A. Not two minutes before, in the parlour cupboard; he went looking round while I was serving him.

JOHN BARKER
(Police-constable B 153). I saw the prisoner running about a quarter of a mile from the house; I suspected all was not right - I took him; he took out his handkerchief, and I saw him clasping something in his hand; I asked what it was, he said "What is that to you?" I found this salt spoon in his hand broken.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 22.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1357.
JOHN SIMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of May , 3 garden pots, value 6d., and 3 plants, value 7s. , the goods of
William Jenkins
.

They being the property of
William Jenkins
and two other executors, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1358.
JAMES SPENCER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of May , 1 box, value 3d., and 1 bracelet, value 12s. , the goods of
George Hickman
.

GEORGE HICKMAN
. I am a jeweller . On the 7th of May I was at the top of Brook-hill, near Ray-street
, just after eight o'clock - I saw some persons near a sledge, on which an iron boiler was drawn; I felt something touch my pocket - I heard somebody say, "Give me my cap?" I turned, and saw the prisoner with a cap on his knees, and I thought he was trying to conceal something - I took him, and in his cap I found this box and bracelet, which I had had in my pocket, and was taking home.

CHARLES FLETCHER
(Police-constable C 137). I took the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Confined 6 Months and
Whipped .

1359.
HENRY THOMAS
and
CHARLES WINTER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May , 2 knives, value 2s. , the goods of
Charles Wright
; to which Thomas
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

The prosecutor's name being
Charles David Wright
, WINTER was
ACQUITTED .

1360.
EDWARD RUMBOLD
and
JANE METCALF
were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of May , 7 lbs. of pork, value 3s. 6d., and 3 lbs. of ham, value 3s. , the goods of
Daniel Davis
.

EDWARD BOND. I am occasionally in the employ of Mr.
Daniel Davis
; he is a cheesemonger . On the night of the 5th of May I was outside serving, and saw the two prisoners together in the shop - there was a pile of pieces of pork; Rumbold looked over it, and I saw Metcalf draw a piece from underneath, but it being slippery it fell on the ground - the man was at this time covering her; I went in, and picked the pork up - the woman coloured very much; I gave it to my fellow-shopman, and said, "John, put this away, it is dirty;" the prisoners then went to the back of the counter, and took a piece of bacon - they put that down, went to the cheese counter, and stood by some ladies, who were being served - they then came to the butter counter, and asked for - lb. of 8d. butter; I then saw Rumbold take this knuckle of ham, and give it to Metcalf, who put it under her apron - they paid for the butter, and were going out; I saw the officer, and called him; Metcalf dropped the ham from under her apron.

JOHN PERKINS. I was serving in the shop. I saw the prisoners come to the back of the shop, and take a pieceof bacon - I had my eyes on them; they put it down, and went to the butter counter - I did not see the ham taken, but saw Metcalf drop it.

JOHN BORRODELL
(Police-constable H 136). I took the prisoners, and have the ham.(Property produced and sworn to.)

RUMBOLD -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

METCALF -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Three Weeks .

1361.
WILLIAM HURLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 1 watch, value 15s. , the goods of
William Gray
.

RUTH GRAY
. I am the wife of
William Gray
- he is a baker . On the 28th of April the prisoner came for some flour for his master; I had no one at home, and I sent him to the bakehouse to get a pie out of the oven, which he did- I then sent him to fetch some coals - a watch, which had usually hung in the bakehouse, was missed the next morning.

SARAH NASH
. I am single - I have known the prisoner about five weeks. On the 28th of April I met him in the New-road, between nine and ten o'clock; he asked me to take a watch to pawn for him, which I took to the Edgware-road, and pawned it in the name of William Roberts, as he told me - I did not know his name.

HENRY MATTHEW BAYFIELD
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Lisson-grove. I took in this watch on the 30th of April, but not from the witness.

SARAH NASH
. I pawned it at another place - it was taken out the second morning, and brought to me; I cannot swear whether this is the watch - it is something like it; I did not notice it - I cannot say whether I think it is - I do not exactly think it is the watch.
Prisoner's Defence. Mrs. Gray sent me for the pie and some coals - there was a boy in the bakehouse.
JURY to MRS. GRAY. Q. Was there any other person in the bakehouse? A. The man who works there came to me at six o'clock, and I paid him - he said all was right, but he is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

1362.
ROBERT HERRING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Adams
, from his person .

THOMAS ADAMS
. I am an umbrella-maker . I was in High-street, St. Giles'
, on the 13th of May - I felt a motion at my side; I turned, and saw the prisoner placing my handkerchief in his breast pocket - he ran; I pursued him, and he threw the handkerchief behind him; I still pursued- the officer saw it - he came behind me, and one of them tripped me up.
PHILIP RILEY. I am an officer. I saw the prosecutor pursuing the prisoner: I saw him throw the handkerchief down and took him.
Prisoner's Defence. Another boy took the handkerchief, and threw it on me - I threw it down, and the gentleman took me.
The prisoner received a good character, and a witness promised to take him as an apprentice.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Whipped and Discharged.

1363.
JOHN HICKMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of April , 4 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 8 half-crowns, and 10 shillings, the monies of
John Stock
, his master .

JOHN STOCK. I live in Princes-street
, and am a hair-dresser . The prisoner has been with me, as a journeyman , about three months; I have known him two years - on the 23rd of April I gave him 6l. (four sovereigns and a half in gold, and the rest in silver), to take to Mr. Myers, my landlord, next door, in part of rent - he returned, said he had given it, and it was all right; he then took a letter to the post, and never returned.

JOSEPH MYERS
. The prosecutor was indebted to me for rent, but the prisoner never brought me any money.

CORNELIUS JOEL PRINCE HEYNDRICKS
(Police-constable C 112). I took the prisoner on this charge; he said he was glad he was in custody, for then he should be punished and all would be over; that he had got intoxicated that evening, and the next morning he had but 24s. or 25s. left.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Confined One Year .

1364.
WILLIAM HADDOCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Fitzgerald
, from his person .

THOMAS HOBBS
(Police-constable C 85). The prosecutor in this case is gone to France, but he gave his name as Thomas Fitzgerald when he was examined. On the 7th of April I was watching the prisoner in Hyde-park
, during a review; I saw him go behind the prosecutor and take this handkerchief from his pocket - he tucked it under his coat, and buttoned it up; I laid hold of him, and took it from him - he was alone, and I believe did it from distress; I gave him something to eat.
GEORGE STONE (Police-constable C 99). I was with Hobbs - what he says is true.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Three Months .

1365.
JOSEPH DIACRE
and
CHARLES MARKES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
William George Brown
, from his person .

WILLIAM GEORGE BROWN
. I am a clerk in a merchant's office. I was in Old-street
between seven and eight o'clock on the 10th of May - I was told I had lost my handkerchief, and missed it; I did not see the prisoner.

WILLIAM COLTON
. I am an officer. I saw the two prisoners follow this gentleman and another down Old-street: and before they got to Golden-lane, I saw Diacre take this handkerchief and give it to Markes - I sent Cadby, who was with me, to tell the gentleman; and in going along Goswell-street we took the prisoners in company again - we put them into a shop, and this handkerchief was picked up there.

JOSEPH CADBY
. I saw the prisoners take the handkerchief, and I have had it ever since.
The prisoners put in a written Defence, stating that they had found the handkerchief on the pavement.

DIACRE -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

MARKES -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Three Months .

1366.
ALFRED COVELL
was indicted for
stealing,on the 8th of May , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Richard Henry
and another.

LAWRENCE JAMES HALES
. I am in the employ of Richard Henry and another, of Bethnal-green-road
- they are pawnbrokers . The prisoner came with another lad; I observed the prisoner snatch a handkerchief down, as he was going out; I followed, and took it from him - he had got about three yards; the other got away.

GEORGE TEAKLE
(Police-constable H 26). I took the prisoner, and have the handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he found the handkerchief on the floor, and was not taking it out; he received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1367.
MARY BIGNEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 1 quilt, value 4s.; 1 sheet, value 1s.; 1 flat-iron, value 6d.; 1 pair of bellows, value 10d.; 1 saucepan, value 2s., and 1 frying-pan, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Elizabeth Pearce
.

ELIZABETH PEARCE
. I am single , and live in Payne's-buildings
. On the 26th of April the prisoner came and hired a back room, furnished, at 3s. 6d. a week - she said that she had a husband; I gave her clean sheets, and a pillow-case; I saw her go out in about five minutes - I followed her to a pawnbroker's; she returned in a few minutes, and told my girl she was not coming back till the Friday, as her daughter was very ill - on the 28th of April she came again, and I gave her a washing-tub; she slept two nights in the room.

RICHARD CHARLES
MARSH. I live with a pawnbroker. I have a sheet and flat-iron, which were pawned by the prisoner on the 26th and 27th of April.

SAMUEL THOMAS KNAPP
. I have a pair of bellows, pawned with me on the 28th of April.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. My husband said he would give me the money to redeem them.

GUILTY . Aged 44. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1368.
THOMAS BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of May , 1 pewter pot, value 1s., the goods of
Patrick Barry
; 1 pewter pot, value 1s., the goods of
Sarah Lee
; and 1 pewter pot, value 1s. , the goods of
Robert Helling
.

PATRICK BARRY
. I keep the Old Bell, in Bond-street
. This pot is mine - I do not know the prisoner.

ANDREW VALLANCE
(Police-constable L 174). I was at the corner of Bond-street, and saw the prisoner go down Duke-street, on the 7th of May, about five o'clock- I followed, and asked what he had got; he made me no answer; I took one pot in this bag, from under his right arm; in going along he took another another pot from his person, and at the watch-house he took this other pot, and put it under the settle.

SARAH LEE. I keep the White Lion, in St. Alban's place
. This pot is mine.

ROBERT HELLING
. I keep the White Swan, in Great Portland-street
. This pot is mine.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to see a gentleman in Bond-street, and in crossing I picked up the bag, which I saw laying down; I found there were two pint pots in it - I took it up; one pot fell from it - I put it into my pocket; I went on, and found another pot; I was turning back to take it home, or to find a pot-boy; the witness then laid hold of me.

GUILTY . Aged 57. -
Confined One Year .

1369.
JAMES ATKINSON
&
GEORGE PLUNKETT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 1 cloak, value 5s. , the goods of
Charles Mumford
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, MAY 23.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1370.
JAMES BRENNAN
was indicted for
feloniously forging a bill of exchange , which is as follows:-March 29, 1832.

Three days after date pay
William Well
, or order, the sum of 20l. which place to account of
JAMES ALDERSOM
.
Messrs. Thomas Westfield, Carlos, and Co., No, 5, Pope's Head-alley, Cornhill.

with intent to defraud
William Venables
and
James Walford
.
SECOND COUNT, for uttering the same.
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

RICHARD VENABLES
. My brother William, and another, carry on business as haberdashers and linendrapers
, in Lamb's Conduit-street
- I assist in the shop. On Tuesday, the 3rd of April , a person came and asked for cash for a bill; it was after the gas was lighted - between five and eight o'clock; I cannot be more particular as to the time - I was in the middle of the shop, No. 75, when he came in; we have more than one shop - I noticed his person, and am positive it was the prisoner; he presented this bill to me, and asked for change for it - I told him it was not customary to change bills for parties we were not acquainted with; he said his name was Boot, that he lived at No. 41, Guildford-street, and was well known in the neighbourhood - his appearance being respectable, and knowing that persons living in that street were respectable, I desired the boy Olney to give him the amount for the bill, and saw him do so - I saw him give him a pen, and saw the prisoner writing on the bill, but was not near enough to see what he wrote; he wished me good night as he went out - the bill was presented next day, and discovered to be forged; on the following Saturday I met the prisoner in Lansdowne-place, by the side of the Foundling - he was round the corner, nearest to Guildford-street (our shop is two doors from Theobald's-road); he was going towards Russell-square - he turned round, and looked at me; I immediately crossed, and overtook him at the corner of Brunswick-square - I asked if he would oblige me with his name and residence; he refused - I do not exactly recollect his words; I then took hold of his arm, and said I wished him to walk with me to Navarino House, Lamb's Conduit-street, immediately, respecting a bill which I had; he said he lived over the water, and wished me to go with him to a friend of his, in Henrietta-street, which is in the neighbourhood of Brunswick-square; I refused - he then told me if I did not loose him he would have a knock at me; he immediately struck me; a scuffle ensued; I eventuallygave him in charge of a Policeman - I called at No. 41, Guildford-street, and found no Mr. Boot living there; Mr. Lucas has lived there many years.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Do you know that the prisoner's defence is an alibi? A. I have been told so - I did not fix the time before I knew that; I can only say the gas was lighted, and it was dark; I had never seen him before - we sell almost every thing at our shop; I was not at that time aware that a bill of this nature should have a stamp - I never saw one like it before - the name of Westfield and Co. is printed; I did not particularly examine it that night - I know this happened after twilight.
MR. BODKIN. Q.Which occupied your attention most, the bill, or the party presenting it? A. The party.

HENRY BENT
. I am apprentice to the prosecutors. On Tuesday, the 3rd of April, I was behind the counter when this bill was brought - Mr. Venables stood nearly opposite me, with his face towards the door; I am certain the prisoner is the person who presented something to Mr. Venables - it was talked of as a bill; I only saw a paper in his hand, which seemed rather dirty - I heard him ask for change; Mr. Venables said it was not customary to do so; I heard nothing else - Mr. Venables sent him up to the desk, and Olney asked him if he would have notes or sovereigns; I saw the prisoner write something on the opposite counter to where I was, and give the paper he wrote on to Olney, who delivered some sovereigns to him; he was in the shop nearly five minutes - there was a gas-light just over where he stood; I saw the prisoner again at Hatton-garden on the Saturday following, and knew him directly I saw him - I cannot say at what time he came, it was after we had our tea; we generally finish tea about a quarter past five or six o'clock - it appeared to be quite dark out of doors; our shop closes between eight and nine - we have no fixed time; I cannot say when we closed that night - I think the prisoner came after six and before nine.

Cross-examined. Q.Will you swear it was after six o'clock? A. I cannot be certain, but should think so - I never heard Mr. Venables say at what time it was; I never heard him say it was half-past four or five o'clock - the prisoner's witnesses were examined at the office; Mrs. Courtney and her husband, and others - I cannot say whether they were sworn.
MR. BODKIN. Q.Was there more than one examination? A. Yes, three - Mr. Venables was examined the first time; I cannot say whether the prisoner's witnesses were examined at the second or third.

DANIEL SUTTON OLNEY. I am cashier to Messrs. Venables. On the 3rd of April, by Mr. Venables' desire, I gave twenty sovereigns for this bill to the prisoner, who wrote his name and address on the back of it, on the counter, in my sight - I did not notice him so as to know him again.
Cross-examined. Q. Perhaps you can give us some notion as to what hour it was? A. I think it was past six o'clock - I had come from tea about half an hour, and generally finish tea about six.

THOMAS BARFORD. I am a Policeman. On Saturday, the 7th of April. I received the prisoner in charge; Mr. Venables was examined at the first and last examination - there were not three; Mr. Venables was examined on the Saturday, the prisoner was remanded till the Saturday following, but nothing was done on account of Mr. Phillips' absence - he was remanded till Monday; there was no examination then, and he was remanded till Thursday the 19th, and then committed; on the day the prisoner was apprehended, he wrote his name and address in my book, here it is (reads) - " J. Brennan, No. 6, North-terrace, Marsh-gate, Lambeth;" Mr. Laing asked a gentleman some questions on the prisoner's behalf at the first examination.

Cross-examined. Q. Who was that gentleman? A. A person from Henrietta-street; Mr. Venables fixed the time at the first examination at between five o'clock and eight; I never heard him fix a nearer time - I think five or six witnesses were examined for the prisoner; I cannot say whether they were sworn - I think they were; Mr. Laing ordered the prisoner to be admitted to bail, in 500l. himself, and four sureties of 250l. - he was not bailed.
MR. BODKIN. Q.How many times was he brought up for examination? A.Only twice.

ROBERT HESKETH PHIPPS
. I live at No. 5, Pope's Head-alley, Cornhill, and have occupied the whole house for seven or eight years - no such persons as Westfield, Carlos, and Co. did business there; I never heard of such a firm, and never saw bills of this kind before.

Prisoner's Defence. I have had no opportunity of explaining the circumstance; the Magistrate behaved very harsh to me, and public reports have gone forth as if I was guilty of the crime; the inconsistency of the nature of the bill must he evident to any gentleman concerned in trade; on the day I was arrested, I was going to Henrietta-street, Brunswick-square, to bring my friend to the Adelphi theatre, for which I had orders, and was going into Brunswick-square, when I felt a touch on my shoulder, and on turning round, I saw a person who was a perfectstranger to me; he requested my name - I asked his object, and when he persevered, I said it was Brennan, and that I lived over the water, thinking he would then perceive his mistake - he says he met me, but he could not, he was behind me; on his stopping me we had a scuffle - I told him to loose my arm; he said he would not - I refused to go with him, not knowing where he would take me; at the examination, as far as I recollect, he named the time to be five o'clock, or thereabouts - I never saw the bill, and my witnesses will prove my occupation during the whole day.

MARY COURTNEY
. I am the wife of
James Courtney
; we live at No. 6, North-terrace, Marsh-gate, Lambeth. I have known the prisoner seven years; he is a landscape-painter, and came over here the latter end of January, at my husband's invitation - he boarded at our house, but did not sleep there; his painting-room was in our house - he has held situations of trust. I remember all the transactions of Tuesday, the 3rd of April; he breakfasted with us that morning, about ten o'clock - he was engaged, finishing a landscape; he went to his painting-room after breakfast- we dined about five o'clock; (the prisoner, my husband, and myself, in the back parlour.) and after dinner removed to the front parlour - my husband is a reporter and attends the Houses of Parliament; his hour of attendance that week was seven o'clock - the prisoner was in our company from five o'clock till my husband went to his duty; I have two children - I did not miss the prisoner from the fire for ten minutes from dinner time till half-past ten at night; I did not miss him at all, but he could not be away ten minutes without my knowing it; there was alittle coolness at that time between my sister-in-law and Mr. Courtney - she came to the house that evening about half-past eight or nine o'clock, and the prisoner saw her part of the way home, at half-past ten o'clock - she lived with us, but was going to a friend of hers, who was in trouble; Needham, a mason, called at our house about seven o'clock that night, and waited about an hour for Mr. Courtney's return - Mr. Courtney went out again between nine and ten o'clock, and did not return till twelve; I am sure the prisoner did not go out.

MR. BODKIN. Q. You have known the prisoner seven years - have you been in Ireland part of that time? A. I have been more than three years in London, but my husband corresponded with him - we are not related. On the 3rd of April the prisoner was very ill - my sister-in-law being out all day, and my servant having left, I was obliged to do every thing myself, and I made soup for him; my servant had left two months before, and my sister-in-law came to stop with me; I have a servant now - she came about three weeks ago; my sister-in-law had been out all that day, and all the night before, which made the day remarkable to me, having so much to do; and I had been ill and was weak then; my husband was learning drawing of the prisoner - I was examined at Hatton-garden at the last examination; my husband and the prisoner drank gin-and-water after dinner, but before dinner they were drawing.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was what you said at the office taken down? A. If it was it was done quickly; I think my husband went out when our clock struck seven, and we keep it ten minutes too fast, on purpose, to give him warning; I was out of the room at times for five minutes; the prisoner was lounging on the sofa, and reading something - I have seen the prisoner write, and believe the paper produced to be written by him; I was asked about that at the office, and said I did not think it was his, but it was then in the clerk's desk, and I only saw the J.B., but when I took it in my hand, and looked at it, I said it was his.

MRS. BYRNE. I am Mr. Courtney's sister. On Monday, the 2nd of April, I went to see a friend, whose husband had been drowned on the Sunday, and staid all night with her; I returned to my brother's about twenty minutes past seven o'clock on Tuesday evening, and on going into the garden in front of the house, and looking in at the window, I saw the prisoner sitting there; I saw nobody else, but he appeared in the act of speaking, and thinking it might be my brother, I was afraid to rap, as there was a coolness between us; I did not go in - I returned in about ten minutes; I still saw the prisoner in the act of talking, and returned up the terrace again; I returned to the house about half-past eight o'clock, and then went into the kitchen - I afterwards heard the door shut, and went into the parlour; my brother had just gone - nobody but the prisoner was there; he was on the sofa, and did not appear in good health; I remained there till half-past ten o'clock, and he then left with me; I went to Mrs. Torren's, New-street, St. James' - he came with me as far as Charing-cross.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you live with Mr. Courtney? A. Yes, since about a week after Christmas; the servant had just gone - I assisted Mrs. Courtney; there are short venetian blinds to the parlour window - they were folded too, but not turned; I swear the prisoner was there.
NOT GUILTY .

1371.
ISABELLA SWAN
,
JAMES DAVIS
, and
HENRY JOHNSON
were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
George Garness
, on the 27th of April , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 chain, value 6d.; 1 seal, value 2s.; 2 keys, value 1s.; 1 purse, value 1d.; 1 half-sovereign, 2 half-crowns, and 1s., his property .

GEORGE GARNESS. I live in Lamb's-passage, Chiswell-street; and am a servant at Mr. Gosbell's stables, On Friday night, the 27th of April, between eleven and twelve o'clock, this happened - I had been drinking ale with Phillips; we had two pints at the St. Paul's, in Chiswell-street - I drank one pint, and felt myself a little merry, but knew what I was about; I was going home, and Phillips asked me to have a pint of beer - we went to the Golden Boot, Milton-street
, about ten minutes past eleven o'clock; Swan sat about three persons from me in the tap-room, under the window - I did not notice the other prisoners - I sat there for about five or ten minutes; they were singing, and called on me for a song; after some persuasion, I attempted to sing, but most of the company made such a howling, I left off, and Phillips got up, and said, "George, let us come out;" I was in the act of following him, when two men pulled me back by my jacket, and pulled me on a seat in the middle of the tap-room; they pressed me to sing again, and I began; Phillips came to the door just after I had left off the second song - (as they made the same noise,) Phillips said I was wanted, that master wanted the keys of the stable; I said I was coming, and got up - I was pulled back by the same two men; Phillips came into the room in a short time, and caught hold of my collar, to bring me out - we had got about the middle of the tap-room, when the gas-light was put out; I had not noticed any of the prisoners but Swan there - I do not know where she was at that time; when the light was put out, I felt Phillips loose his hold of my collar, and I received a blow on my legs - I was tripped up - I fell on my back on the floor; the tap-room door being directly opened, I saw a man's hand; he had a great coat on - I saw he had got my watch-chain, which he broke from my watch; the watch was then hanging to my guard, out of my fob; Swan took it off the guard; I could see her by the light from the bar, as the tap-room door was open, and I was close to it- there were several women in the house; I did not know Swan before - I caught hold of Swan's clothes, by which means I was able to raise myself up - I had made a snatch at the watch as she took it from the guard - it fell from her hand on the ground, and was kicked from there; I do not by whom - Swan picked it up, and put into her bosom; I stood by the tap-room door; Swan was close by me - I called to Atkinson, the landlord, "I have been robbed of my watch;" I did not tell him who had taken it, because there was such a scuffle - I was so exhausted, I could hardly speak; I had hold of Swan at that time; I let go of her as some people came huddling by me - I was pushed away from her, and at that moment Phillips came to me with my purse, and said, "Here is yourmoney, I took it from that man," pointing to Johnson, who was within hearing - Swan was making towards the front door, which leads into the street; the Policeman was coming in at the time - Mrs. Atkinson, the landlady, said to him, "Stop that woman! she has got the watch;" he stopped her - she drew nearer to the counter with the Policeman; I saw her draw the watch from her bosom, and give it to him, saying, "There is the watch" - the Policeman kept it; the chain, seal, and keys were entirely gone from it - I did not see Davis in the house at all, but as the Policeman was taking Swan to the station, Davis came and said he should not take her, for she was his wife; Gladwell took Johnson, and another took Davis.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.You had your senses about you? A.Perfectly so - I sang very little; I do not recollect seeing Davis in the house.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.You went to one or two public-houses? A. To the St. Paul's public-house; I am sure I had no spirits - they wanted me to drink some gin; I refused, and they spilt it down my neck - I do not know who that was; I knocked the glass away and none went down my throat - I gave the same evidence before the Magistrate, and did not want Phillips to remind me of any thing; I once thought of leaving this prosecution alone, as I was afraid of losing my situation - I never heard Phillips tell the Policeman he should have 3s. 6d. a day; he never said so in my hearing.

Q. Were not you so drunk that Swan picked up your watch, and gave it to Phillips to save for you? A. No, she did not - the landlord and landlady saw her take it from her bosom when the Policeman came in; I did not want more drink there, which was refused - when the tap-room door was pushed open I could see by the light from the bar.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Had you been sparring with Phillips? A.No; there were a great many people in the tap-room - I do not know at what time I lost my purse; I bottoned my breeches pocket up a moment before Phillips came in - that was before the two men pulled me back; when I saw Johnson he stood facing the door - I cannot swear he was in the room when my watch was taken - I did not see him till Phillips brought my purse, and pointed to him; it could not have fallen from my pocket - Peak, the Policeman, did not tell me to say the prisoners were the persons, or they would get off - it was Phillips gave Johnson in charge.

HENRY PHILLIPS. I am cook at an eating-house in Chiswell-street. I went with Garness to the Boot, and had a pint of ale - I had passed through the St. Paul's public-house when he was there, but I drank nothing; we both went into the Golden Boot between eleven and twelve o'clock, and had a pint of beer between us at the bar, and as there was singing in the tap-room, Garness said, "Let us go in, and hear a song, and drink the rest there" - we went in and sat down ten or eleven minutes; they called on Garness for a song - I saw Swan and Davis in the room at that time; Garness attempted to sing, but they howled, and he left off - I got up and said, "We had better be going;" he said, "Stop a bit" - I did not see him follow me; I was not out half a minute, and when I came in again he had shifted his seaf, and was sitting between two or three men, who called on him to sing again.

Q. Had you seen any thing when you said he had better be going? A. I saw some persons rubbing their hands across his pockets, and thought all was not right - I went out, came in again, and, to get him out, said,"George, your master wants the keys of the stable;" he got up, and attempted to come out - they pulled him down, and said, "Let him finish his song;" that was neither of the prisoners - they began to sing again; I asked if he was coming - he attempted to get up, and was pulled down again by the same persons - I went over to the house opposite, to get somebody to pull him out; I was not gone half a minute - I returned, and saw him sitting quietly in the same company as before; I laid hold of his collar to pull him out, and the gas was immediately put out - I heard somebody in the room say ding; I was struck, and a bad expression used to me - I was separated from him; I ran to the tap-room door, and opened it - that threw a light into the room; I saw Swan round him and Johnson, but did not see Davis - I saw Swan drop the watch; she then kicked it into the bar; I saw Johnson take the purse out of Garness' pocket - I snatched it from his hand; Garness was then on his back on the tap-room floor; I saw Johnson's hand come from the pocket with the purse-Swan and others were making their way out of the room, and the landlady said, "Stop that woman, she has got his watch in her bosom;" I got hold of it, and the Policeman took it out of my hand - Davis came up, and said she was his wife, and should not go to the watch-house - he was in the house; the Policeman took her to the station - there was an attempt to rescue Swan, and by that means they were all secured.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. It was nearly all over before Davis interfered? A. He was in the room all the time, but I only saw him attempt the rescue - I was sober.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Was the prosecutor sober? A.He was half and half - he knew what he was about; he had no gin at the Boot; I have left my situation because I was not satisfied with my food; I have not talked with the Policeman about how much a day I should get here.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. You made no charge against Johnson at the station? A. No; I do not know whether he was locked up for an assault - the robbery was committed in the middle of the tap-room, right opposite the door.

GEORGE ATKINSON
. I am landlord of the Golden Boot. I was inside my bar the early part of the evening - the three prisoners came in about eight o'clock, in company with two men, and about eleven Garness and Phillips came in - they had some beer in the tap-room; they had no spirits, to my knowledge; after they went into the tap-room I heard the prosecutor singing - he was sitting under the window; I had not heard singing before - I observed some of my customers near him, but not either of the prisoners were at that time near him; I then returned to the bar, and was standing there; Johnson came out with two women, and called for some gin - I do not recollect whether Swan was one of them or not; while Johnson was drinking at the bar a Policeman came in, and said,"Take in a light;" I took a candle into the tap-room, and found the gas-light out - I lighted it directly, andsaw the prosecutor laying on the floor - Phillips had hold of his collar; I stopped there a little while, then came out, and heard somebody say, "This is the woman who has got the watch" (I had heard the prosecutor say nothing); I did not see what woman was meant, and who said so I do not know; I saw the Policeman come in, and he took the female prisoner by the side of the bar - I did not see the watch taken from her, nor see it at all.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Did you see Swan standing at the bar with Davis' wife? A. A young woman was drinking there with Davis; Swan was in and out that evening - two women and two men were at the bar at the time the light was called for, but whether one was Swan I cannot say; the bar is on the same side as the tap-room; when the gas was out I do not think a person could see what was passing, till I took the candle - a great many people were running in and out; I am sure nobody could see, for I am in the habit of going in when the gas is out - it was as I came out from lighting the gas that somebody said the woman had the watch - I did not see it kicked by anybody, but after they were taken to the station-house I saw the remains of the watch-glass close to where the prosecutor lay; when I heard my wife say"She has got the watch," I saw it open in Swan's hand, not in her bosom - the Policeman ran in at that moment; she was standing in front of the bar, not attempting to go out; Garness was so drunk, that at the station-house he could not give a word of his statement; he sat in a chair there, and shammed a fit - Phillips was not drunk; two strange bad characters had come into my house, and at the time of the robbery they ran out.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.Are you sure Johnson came out of the tap-room with two women before you heard the noise? A.They were outside at the time the robbery was committed, and I left Johnson standing at the bar when I went, in and found Garness on the floor - I did not see Phillips take the purse from Johnson, nor hear it mentioned either at the house or station - it was about half-past eleven o'clock.
COURT. Q. Do you keep your house open so late? We are allowed to keep open till twelve o'clock all round the neighbourhood.

- ATKINSON. I am the landlady. The first thing I saw was the prisoners standing at my bar - Garness ran out, put his back to the door, and said, "Oh, I am robbed, I have lost my master's watch;" at that time Johnson and Swan were at the bar - Johnson had just called for a quartern of gin; Swan stood with her right arm at the corner of the bar - I saw her stoop down, and pick up a watch with her right hand; I never saw it in her bosom - she picked it up between the bar and the tap-room door - the prosecutor was so tipsy he could not stand; he reeled from the door, and the Policeman came in; I said,"Here is the woman who has got the watch;" the Policeman took her round to the right-hand side of the bar, and she delivered the watch to him - she had it open in her hand before that - neither Garness nor Phillips said any thing about her taking it at that time; when Garness saw it in her hand he charged her with it - when the Policeman came; he could scarcely stand then.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Did you tell any body to stop Swan? A. I did not - I said, "Policeman, here is the woman who has the watch;" she was not attempting to go away - she could have no hand in stealing the watch.

MATTHEW PEAK
. I am a Policeman. I was going by the house on my beat, and heard singing - I looked through the window, and saw Phillips go towards Garness; they sat right opposite the tap-room door - he said something, but I could not hear what; after he had been there about a moment the gas was put out or went out - I then put my head in, and told Atkinson to take a light in; he was in the bar at the time - there were men and women standing at the bar, but I cannot say who; in three or four minutes I heard Garness say he was robbed of his watch - he was then in front of the bar, and had come out of the tap-room- he had been drinking, but was not so drunk but what he knew what he was about - as soon as I heard he had lost his watch I entered the house, and Swan was then coming out of the street door - I had not seen her at the bar; Mrs. Atkinson said, "Stop that woman, she has got the watch; she has got it in her bosom" - I went to get hold of her; she put her right hand into her bosom, and took the watch out - it had no chain or seal to it then; she was not standing at the bar - I am quite sure Mrs. Atkinson said she had it in her bosom; and I saw her take it from her bosom - Mrs. Atkinson was in the bar at that time, but I think Mr. Atkinson was in the tap-room; as Swan took the watch from her bosom Phillips held his hand out to get hold of it, but I took it from him - after I got the watch I put Swan into the passage, and sent for assistance, because I had been ill-used before by taking persons out of that house; the landlord sent a boy to the station for assistance, and a man came and kept the people back while I took her out - Davis claimed her as his wife in the public-house - Atkinson and his wife were there; Davis took hold of her gown, and said, "Come away, are not you coming home?" he said she was his wife - he pulled me by the sleeve, but used no violence there; when I had got Swan twenty or thirty yards from the house, Johnson came behind and hit me on the back of the head; I had heard no charge against him then - I called for a Policeman, and Gladwell took him - Garness came to the watch-house; he said the watch did not belong to him, and raved about it, so that as last he went into a fit - before that he was sensible, and knew what he was doing - when Johnson struck me he sprang the rattle for me.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Have you heard Mrs. Atkinson's evidence? A. I have - on my oath she told me to stop Swan; Garness came to me after the parties were fully committed, and said, "Some of their friends have been to me, what am I to do? "I said, "You are bound over to appear, and may do as you like;" he said something about being afraid that he should lose his place in consequence of the time it would take - the public-houses are open till twelve o'clock; we have no orders to prevent it - Mrs. Atkinson's name was struck from the back of the indictment, by the clerk, at the time we were sworn, as she was gone away ill in a coach; she was present when the bill went before the Grand Jury, but was not called -I did not know what she would state; she contradicted me before the Magistrate, respecting Swan's coming out of the door.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.How long wereyou in the house? A. I dare say ten minutes altogether; when I got a certificate from the Magistrate, Phillips asked why I had two papers; I said one was a certificate for 3s. 6d. a day - he did not tell me he had seen Johnson's hands come from the prosecutor's pocket, and that he took the purse from him, till next morning.

GEORGE GLADWELL
. I am a Policeman. I was in Chiswell-street, and met a boy coming to the station - he sent me to the Boot, where I found Peak, who asked me to keep the people away while he got Swan out; when he a few steps from the door, he called out - I went up, and saw Johnson strike him once or twice on the back of the head - I secured him; Davis was on the spot, and I received several blows from somebody.

FREDERICK MILES. I am a Policeman. Atkinson's servant fetched me from the station; I found Johnson in Gladwell's custody - Davis said I should not take him away, as he was his brother, and I took him for attempting to rescue Johnson; Atkinson and his brother forfeited their recognizances yesterday against another prisoner.
Swan's Defence. What the prosecutor has sworn is false - it is not in my nature to do any thing of the kind.

Johnson's Defence. I came out of the tap-room to go home, and during that time two men whom I knew came in, and we had something to drink at the bar; while it was being poured out the other two prisoners came out to the bar, and partook of what I was drinking - a man named Sadler came out; he had been singing - he stood there talking: a scuffle eusued in the tap-room, but I never moved from the bar - a watch was kicked out of the tap-room; the female prisoner took it up - I never offered to go from the bar till she was taken out; I then went to see where she was going - the Policeman then collared and dragged me away; the prosecutor was very much intoxicated - the Policeman said I was taken for an assault; they said nothing about the purse. In the morning, at the office, the prosecutor said to the Policeman, "Is that the woman?" he touched him with his elbow, and said, "Yes, and these are the two men - you must mind what you say, or they will get off," and then they charged us all with the robbery.

CHARLES NUTT. I live in Holywell-lane. I went into the Boot at ten o'clock on the night in question, and saw the prosecutor, who I have known for years, sitting between two young men, singing; he told me he had been to sea - he was a little intoxicated: I told him his master wanted to speak to him outside, as he had the key of the stable, thinking if I got him out he might be induced to go home - Phillips was not in the room then; several songs were sang - I saw him drink three glasses of gin, which two young men gave him, and several times he drank out of different pots of porter; I then tried to prevail on him to go home, but he said, "Mind your own business," and that he would cut my head with a quart pot; he called for more gin - one of the men who sat on his right, called for a quartern, and poured out a glass - he was so tipsy he could scarcely take it; the prisoners were not those men when I went in the male prisoners were at the further end of the room, at some distance from him; the young men put the gin to his mouth; he drank some, and some he spilt down his clothes - he then began to sing another song- there was no room for me to sit; I stood at the tap-room door, and had another pint of half-and-half; Swan and Johnson asked a young man who had sung to come and have something to drink at the bar; nothing had been done to the prosecutor at that time, for I stood opposite him; Swan and Johnson left the room, and stood - I stood aside, opened the door, and let them out with two more young men; when they had been out about five minutes, three young men came into the tap-room, and took the seats they had left, by the fire-place, and in a few minutes the gas was put out - I thought it was done accidentally; I opened the door, and told Atkinson they were in the dark - he ran in with a light; I did not go into the room again, but sat on a table opposite the bar; when Atkinson took in the light I saw the prosecutor laying on the ground - Swan was then at the bar, drinking spirits, and Johnson had the measure in his hand, close to her; there was another young man with them - the tap-room was nearly full - as soon as the door was opened people rushed out into the street, and I saw the watch kicked out of the taproom; Swan stooped and took it up as she stood at the bar- it is impossible that she could have interfered in the robbery; she had left the tap-room for a quarter of an hour -Mrs. Atkinson said, "This woman has got the watch;" she was not going away - Atkinson did not say Stop her! the watch was open in her hand - the prosecutor said, "Give me the watch, and I will run away, for I will never give any body in charge;" a Policeman coming in saw her with the watch in her hand, and took her in charge by the bar; she never had the watch in her bosom, on my oath; it was in her hand, and partly in the prosecutor's hand - she was in the act of giving it to him when the Policeman came in; I was holding him at the time, for he could scarcely stand.

COURT. Q.What are you? A. A house-painter - I believe the prosecutor had his senses so as to know what he was saying - any body could hear what he said; I cannot say whether Mrs. Atkinson heard it - I was close to her, but she was the only person to take care of the bar - she might not have heard it; she said, "That woman has the watch," but that was not to the Policeman - it was before he came in; she said it to the prosecutor - I cannot say she did not say it again when the Policeman was there- I do not think she did.
NOT GUILTY .

1372.
FRANCIS HENRY PEMELLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of May , 15 sovereigns, 8 half-crowns, 15 shillings, and 10 sixpences, the monies of
Richard Marshall
and another, his employers . - To which he
pleaded GUILTY .

Strongly recommended to Mercy -
Confined Three Months .

1373.
JANE LOVELL
and
REBECCA WILD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 13 yards of ribbon, value 7s. , the goods of
Thomas Hall
.

JAMES EYNON
. I am shopman to Thomas Hall, linen-draper , Bishopsgate
. On the 11th of April, between three and four o'clock, the prisoners came into the shop together, and asked for some bonnet ribbon, and I served them; Lovell took several ribbons out of the drawer and unrolled them - she attempted to take one piece, but lost it the firsttime, and at last she took it; Wild at last bought two yards, which she paid for - they went out; I went after them, brought them back, and Lovell dropped the ribbon in the shop.

Cross-examined by MR. WALESBY. Q.Can you recollect how many customers you had in the shop? A. Only one while they were there, to the best of my belief -Lovell took the ribbons out of the drawer, and gave them to the other prisoner, after unfolding them, and she put them into the drawer again, unfolded, so that the drawer was in confusion; Lovell reached over the drawer, covering it with her shawl, and took a ribbon, but caught my eye, and dropped it - she made a second attempt, and took it; I think she put it in her breast - I saw it drop from her when I brought them back.
JAMES BLEECHMORE. I am an officer. I took them into custody; I took a basket from Lovell, and found in it another piece of ribbon, claimed by Mr. Rotherham.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Lovell's Defence. I bought both pieces of ribbon in Rosemary-lane, of a young woman with carrotty hair, for 5s. 6d. - she said she would not sell one without the other; as I returned I met Wild, who asked me to go with her to buy some ribbon; I showed her mine, she did not like it -I went with her to a shop in Houndsditch; she bought two yards; I said I did not like it, and put her out of conceit of it, and she asked me to go into this shop to buy another.

LOVELL -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

WILD -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoners.

1374.
RICHARD HOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 3d., the goods of
George Bown
, from his person .

GEORGE BOWN
. I am a musician . On the 28th of April, about ten o'clock, I was in Fore-street
- I did not feel my handkerchief taken, but missed it as I came out of a public-house; the prisoner was taken in five minutes.

THOMAS CADE
. I saw the prisoner and a little boy standing at the top of Milton-street - they went behind the prosecutor, and I saw the little boy take his hand from the prosecutor's pocket; they walked away up Fore-street - the prisoner was standing behind the little one; I am sure of his person - the boy ran away when he saw the prisoner was taken.

THOMAS NORWOOD. I was in Fore-street, and saw a boy take a handkerchief out of the prosecutor's pocket and give it to the prisoner, who stood just behind him; he was secured, and the handkerchief found.

WILLIAM BRAND
. I am a marshalsman. I heard a witness say the prisoner had gone up Milton-street - I followed, and took him and the boy, but in scuffling with the prisoner the other party let the boy go; I found the handkerchief in the prisoner's pocket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I beg for mercy.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1375.
CHARLES WILLIAMS
was indicted for
feloliously uttering two forged requests for the delivery of goods , with intent to defraud
Charles Powell
and another. - To which he
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 54. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1376.
JOSEPH JENN
was indicted for
feloniously uttering a forged receipt for goods , with intent to defraud
Isaac Bird
and another.

ISAAC BIRD
. I am in partnership with
Robert Johnson
; we carry on business as ironmongers and hardwaremen in Fenchurch-street
. The prisoner was in our employ for about eleven months, and left on the 23rd of April - this receipt came into my hands, and was posted in my books as a genuine receipt; the prisoner was entrusted to take orders and receive money - I do not know Mr. Tutt's handwriting; the prisoner was in our employ at the date of the receipt.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Where did you get that paper? A.From a drawer in our counting-house, which our warehouseman and clerk have access to; it is an open drawer - I have only one customer named Tutt; his Christian name is John - there is no address in the receipt; I will swear the receipt is in the prisoner's hand-writing.

Q. If he had not sold the goods to Tutt, this would be the readiest way to lead to a discovery? A. Yes, he generally writes his orders in his memorandum book, but this is a receipt; I should think the signature was not the prisoner's writing, but the body of it is.

ROBERT JOHNSON. I am in partnership with Mr. Bird. Tutt is a customer of ours; part of the goods named in this receipt were delivered to us from Birmingham, on the 17th of February - the prisoner had told me before that he had an order for chisels from Tutt, of Wilstead-street; on the morning of the 18th, when he came, I told him the chisels had come, and he had better take them out with him - I afterwards found they were gone from the shelves; they must have been taken by the prisoner or our warehouseman - on the same evening the prisoner brought me this receipt, which it was his duty to do, if he had delivered the goods; he gave it me as the genuine receipt of Tutt - I put it into the drawer, or gave it to Mr. Bird - something having occurred afterwards respecting the prisoner's conduct, I delivered accounts to our customers - Tutt pointed out these articles as never having been ordered or received; I produced to him different receipts - he said this was forged.

Cross-examined. Q.When goods were heavy, who took them out? A.Our porter; if more than 120l. worth of town business was done in a month with retail shops, the prisoner was to have a quarter per cent; he had 25s. a week certain; that sum has never been exceeded, and we owed him no commission - we never allowed him to purchase goods with our money - I never knew him take goods to customers, who had not ordered them, when intended for another customer who did not like them.

JOHN TUTT
. I am a smith. I never ordered these goods; I never received them, nor signed this receipt - I do not sell these sort of goods - (read).
Received from Bird and Johnson, the 18th of February, 1832, 3 sugar cleavers, 1 dozen of chisels, 3 ladies' hammers, half a dozen plyers, and 2 pairs of brass candlesticks. J. TUTT.

GUILTY . Aged 44. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
There were two other indictments against the prisoner for embezzlement, and the prosecutors stated their loss at 320l.

1377.
CHARLOTTE HOLLAND
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .
MESSRS. PRENDERGAST and BARRY conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS WATSON
. I am overseer of St. Mary, Aldermanbury. I commenced giving the prisoner parochial relief on the 6th of April, 1831, and continued to do so till the 28th of March, when I went out of office - I paid her 3s. a week at first, and increased it on the 30th of November to 4s.; I have paid her altogether 10l. 8s., believing her to be chargeable on our parish - she presented herself as a pauper of that parish at the vestry, weekly - her name was in the book which was handed to me by my predecessor.

Cross-examined by MR. ROWE. Q. How are the entries made in that book? A.Weekly - the casual poor are entered in a different account; she made no representation to me, except coming with the other paupers, and taking the weekly allowance.
MR. BARRY. Q. Was she entered as a weekly pauper before you came into office? A. Yes, and I find, in 1830, an instrument was bought for her to go to work with.

BENJAMIN BROWN. I am one of the parish officers of St. Mary, the Virgin, Aldermanbury - I came into office on the 4th of April. The prisoner applied to me that day for her weekly allowance; I paid her 6s.; Mr. Watson had given me the list, and had reduced her allowance to 3s. a week, which she refused to take, saying she had a great deal of illness in her family, and I gave her 6s.
Cross-examined. Q. You know nothing of her settlement? A. No.

JOSEPH WEST
. I am master of the workhouse of St. James', Clerkenwell. I have paid the prisoner 5s. a week from the 3rd of June 1829, to the 14th of March 1832.

JAMES HILL. I am clerk to the vestry-clerk of Clerkenwell. I took and examination of the prisoner's husband, and at his death, of herself - she claimed a settlement on her husband's apprenticeship in 1829.
Cross-examined. Q. Was there ever any question about her settlement? A.Never; she said her husband died at sea.
GUILTY . Aged 25.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .
NEW COURT, WEDNESDAY, MAY 23.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1378.
THOMAS BAKER
and
HENRY McGEE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 1 necklace, value 8s., the goods of
Charles Barnes
, from
Maria Barnes
; and that Henry McGee had been before convicted of felony .

MARY BARNES. I am the wife of
Charles Barnes
; my daughter Maria is eight years old; I put a necklace on her neck on the 1st of May; I afterwards saw her without it.

MARIA BARNES. I am the daughter of Charles Barnes. On the 1st of May I went out with Mrs. Lathan, to look at the chimney-sweepers; I had a necklace on -Baker snatched it off my neck, and gave it to the other prisoner, who ran away towards the market; I laid hold of Baker's coat, and some persons came to my assistance.

JOHN MEARS. I am the son of
William Mears
. I was in Bath-street on the 1st of May, looking at the sweepers; I saw Baker snatch the necklace off
Maria Barnes
